*“It is The Morning Chronicle of April 27, 1890. Just two months ago. I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, with the intention of asking him whether he would care to accompany me to the theatre that evening, when he suddenly pushed his chair back from the table and said:—*  

*‘By the way, Watson, I suppose you have never read any of the advertisements in The Morning Chronicle?’*  

*‘Why, yes,’ I answered, in some surprise at this abrupt question. ‘I have just glanced over them.’*  

*‘Then you have missed the one which concerns the Red-Headed League?’*  

*‘No, I saw that. “To the Red-Headed League: On account of the bequest of the late Ezekiah Hopkins—”’*  

*‘Precisely. Now, Mr. Jabez Wilson here has been good enough to call upon me this morning, and to begin a narrative which promises to be one of the most singular which I have listened to for some time. You have heard me remark that the strangest and most unique things are very often connected not with the larger but with the smaller crimes, and occasionally, indeed, where there is room for doubt whether any positive crime has been committed. As far as I have heard, it is impossible for me to say whether the present case is an instance of crime or not, but the course of events is certainly among the most singular that I have ever listened to. Perhaps, Mr. Wilson, you would have the great kindness to recommence your narrative. I ask you not merely because my friend Dr. Watson has not heard the opening part but also because the peculiar nature of the story makes me anxious to have every possible detail from your lips. As a rule, when I have heard some slight indication of the course of events, I am able to guide myself by the thousands of other similar cases which occur to my memory. In the present instance I am forced to admit that the facts are, to the best of my belief, unique.’*  

*The portly client puffed out his chest with an appearance of some little pride and pulled a dirty and wrinkled newspaper from the inside pocket of his greatcoat. As he glanced down the advertisement column, with his head thrust forward, and the paper flattened out upon his knee, I took a good look at the man and endeavoured, after the fashion of my companion, to read the indications which might be presented by his dress or appearance.*  

*I did not gain very much, however, by my inspection. Our visitor bore every mark of being an average commonplace British tradesman, obese, pompous, and slow. He wore rather baggy grey shepherd’s check trousers, a not over-clean black frock-coat, unbuttoned in the front, and a drab waistcoat with a heavy brassy Albert chain, and a square pierced bit of metal dangling down as an ornament. A frayed top-hat and a faded brown overcoat with a wrinkled velvet collar lay upon a chair beside him. Altogether, look as I would, there was nothing remarkable about the man save his blazing red head and the expression of extreme chagrin and discontent upon his features.*  

*Sherlock Holmes’ quick eye took in my occupation, and he shook his head with a smile as he noticed my questioning glances. ‘Beyond the obvious facts that he has at some time done manual labour, that he takes snuff, that he is a Freemason, that he has been in China, and that he has done a considerable amount of writing lately, I can deduce nothing else,’ said he.*  

*Mr. Jabez Wilson started up in his chair, with his forefinger upon the paper, but his eyes upon my companion. ‘How, in the name of good-fortune, did you know all that, Mr. Holmes?’ he asked. ‘How did you know, for example, that I did manual labour? It’s as true as gospel, for I began as a ship’s carpenter.’*  

*‘Your hands, my dear sir. Your right hand is quite a size larger than your left. You have worked with it, and the muscles are more developed.’*  

*‘Well, the snuff, then, and the Freemasonry?’*  

*‘I won’t insult your intelligence by telling you how I read that, especially as, rather against the strict rules of your order, you use an arc-and-compass breastpin.’*  

*‘Ah, of course, I forgot that. But the writing?’*  

*‘What else can be indicated by that right cuff so very shiny for five inches, and the left one with the smooth patch near the elbow where you rest it upon the desk?’*  

*‘Well, but China?’*  

*‘The fish which you have tattooed immediately above your right wrist could only have been done in China. I have made a small study of tattoo marks, and have even contributed to the literature of the subject. That trick of staining the fishes’ scales of a delicate pink is quite peculiar to China. When, in addition, I see a Chinese coin hanging from your watch-chain, the matter becomes even more simple.’*  

*Mr. Jabez Wilson laughed heavily. ‘Well, I never!’ said he. ‘I thought at first that you had done something clever, but I see that there was nothing in it after all.’*  

*‘I begin to think, Watson,’ said Holmes, ‘that I make a mistake in explaining. “Omne ignotum pro magnifico,” you know, and my poor little reputation, such as it is, will suffer shipwreck if I am so candid. Can you not find the advertisement, Mr. Wilson?’*  

*‘Yes, I have got it now,’ he answered, with his thick red finger planted halfway down the column. ‘Here it is. This is what began it all. You just read it for yourself, sir.’*  

*I took the paper from him and read as follows:—*  

*‘TO THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE: On account of the bequest of the late Ezekiah Hopkins, of Lebanon, Pennsylvania, U.S.A., there is now another vacancy open which entitles a member of the League to a salary of £4 a week for purely nominal services. All red-headed men who are sound in body and mind, and above the age of twenty-one years, are eligible. Apply in person on Monday, at eleven o’clock, to Duncan Ross, at the offices of the League, 7 Pope’s Court, Fleet Street.’*  

*When I had finished, Holmes chuckled to himself and rubbed his long, nervous hands together. ‘Rather a curious business, is it not?’ said he. ‘Pray continue your most interesting statement.’*  

*‘Well, I had a small pawnbroker’s business at Coburg Square, near the City, which has lately been not very profitable. I had two assistants, but only one now, and I should hardly be able to pay him but that he is willing to come for half wages so as to learn the business.’*  

*‘What is the name of this obliging youth?’ asked Sherlock Holmes.*  

*‘His name is Vincent Spaulding, and he’s not such a youth, either. It’s hard to say his age. He’s a smart fellow, is Spaulding—I know no more of him than that he is smart, and that he is willing to work for half wages.’*  

*‘Yes, yes; he seems a smart fellow, this Vincent Spaulding of yours. Pray continue.’*  

*‘Well, he answered the advertisement, and he went to the address given, and he was engaged. That was eight weeks ago last Monday. The salary was to be four pounds a week, and the hours from ten to two. I thought it was a fine thing, and I was very glad to get it.’*  

*‘What were his duties?’*  

*‘They were to copy out the “Encyclopædia Britannica.” He was to start at the letter “A,” and to go right through till he had finished it. He was to sit in the office from ten till two, and he was to have a quart of ink provided for him every Monday morning. He was to have nothing else to do but to copy the “Encyclopædia.”’*  

*‘Nothing else?’*  

*‘Nothing.’*  

*‘And he has stuck to it?’*  

*‘Oh, yes, sir. He has been very regular. He has never missed a day, and he has never been more than a few minutes late.’*  

*‘Has he done anything else?’*  

*‘No, sir, nothing. He has been very quiet and steady. He has never gone out, except at the regular times, and he has never had any visitors.’*  

*‘And the work?’*  

*‘Oh, he has got on very well with it. He has done a volume a week, and he is now at the letter “B.”’*  

*‘And what is his handwriting like?’*  

*‘Oh, it’s very good, sir—small and neat.’*  

*‘And he has never asked for any help?’*  

*‘No, sir, never.’*  

*‘And he has never seemed puzzled?’*  

*‘No, sir. He has always seemed to understand what he was about.’*  

*‘Well, Watson, what do you make of it?’ Holmes asked, suddenly turning to me.*  

*‘I don’t know what to make of it. It is a most extraordinary business.’*  

*‘Yes, and Mr. Wilson here is the victim of a most extraordinary swindle.’*  

*‘A swindle?’ cried Mr. Wilson, starting up. ‘But I have had my four pounds a week regular.’*  

*‘Oh, yes, you have had your money. But what have you done for it? You have copied out the “Encyclopædia Britannica.” You have been at work for eight weeks, and you are now at the letter “B.” You have a long way before you get to the end of the alphabet.’*  

*‘Well, sir, I thought it was a bit of luck at the time. But, of course, I see now that it was a swindle. But what I want to know is, what is the object of it all? Why should anyone take the trouble to play such a trick upon me?’*  

*‘That is what we have to find out, Mr. Wilson. And first, I should like to ask you a few questions. How long had this assistant of yours been with you before the advertisement appeared?’*  

*‘About a month.’*  

*‘How did he come?’*  

*‘In answer to an advertisement.’*  

*‘Was he the only applicant?’*  

*‘No, I had a dozen.’*  

*‘Why did you pick him?’*  

*‘Because he was handy and would come cheap.’*  

*‘At half wages, in fact.’*  

*‘Yes.’*  

*‘What is he like, this Vincent Spaulding?’*  

*‘Small, stout-built, very quick in his ways, no hair on his face, though he’s not short of thirty. Has a white splash of acid upon his forehead.’*  

*Holmes sat up in his chair in considerable excitement. ‘I thought as much,’ said he. ‘Have you ever observed that his ears are pierced for earrings?’*  

*‘Yes, sir. He told me that a gipsy had done it for him when he was a lad.’*  

*‘Hum!’ said Holmes, sinking back in deep thought. ‘He is still with you?’*  

*‘Oh, yes, sir; I have only just left him.’*  

*‘And has your business been attended to in your absence?’*  

*‘Nothing to complain of, sir. There’s never very much to do of a morning.’*  

*‘That will do, Mr. Wilson. I shall be happy to give you an opinion upon the subject in the course of a day or two. To-day is Saturday, and I hope that by Monday we may come to a conclusion.’*  

*‘Well, Watson,’ said Holmes, when our visitor had left us, ‘what do you make of it all?’*  

*‘I make nothing of it,’ I answered, frankly. ‘It is a most mysterious business.’*  

*‘As a rule,’ said Holmes, ‘the more bizarre a thing is the less mysterious it proves to be. It is your commonplace, featureless crimes which are really puzzling, just as a commonplace face is the most difficult to identify. But I must be prompt over this matter.’*  

*‘What are you going to do, then?’ I asked.*  

*‘To smoke,’ he answered. ‘It is quite a three pipe problem, and I beg that you won’t speak to me for fifty minutes.’*  

*He curled himself up in his chair, with his thin knees drawn up to his hawk-like nose, and there he sat with his eyes closed and his black clay pipe thrusting out like the bill of some strange bird. I had come to the conclusion that he had dropped asleep, and indeed was nodding myself, when he suddenly sprang out of his chair with the gesture of a man who has made up his mind and put his pipe down upon the mantelpiece.*  

*‘Sarasate plays at the St. James’s Hall this afternoon,’ he remarked. ‘What do you think, Watson? Could your patients spare you for a few hours?’*  

*‘I have nothing to do to-day. My practice is never very absorbing.’*  

*‘Then put on your hat and come. I am going through the City first, and we can have some lunch on the way. I observe that there is a good deal of German music on the programme, which is rather more to my taste than Italian or French. It is introspective, and I want to introspect. Come along!’*  

*We travelled by the Underground as far as Aldersgate; and a short walk took us to Saxe-Coburg Square, the scene of the singular story which we had listened to in the morning. It was a poky, little, shabby-genteel place, where four lines of dingy two-storied brick houses looked out into a small railed-in enclosure, where a lawn of weedy grass and a few clumps of faded laurel-bushes made a hard fight against a smoke-laden and uncongenial atmosphere. Three gilt balls and a brown board with “JABEZ WILSON” in white letters, upon a corner house, announced the place where our red-headed client carried on his business. Sherlock Holmes stopped in front of it with his head on one side and looked it all over, with his eyes shining brightly between puckered lids. Then he walked slowly up the street, and then down again to the corner, still looking keenly at the houses. Finally he returned to the pawnbroker’s, and, having thumped vigorously upon the pavement with his stick two or three times, he went up to the door and knocked. It was instantly opened by a bright-looking, clean-shaven young fellow, who asked him to step in.*  

*‘Thank you,’ said Holmes, ‘I only wished to ask you how you would go from here to the Strand.’*  

*‘Third right, fourth left,’ answered the assistant promptly, and closed the door.*  

*‘Smart fellow, that,’ observed Holmes as we walked away. ‘He is, in my judgment, the fourth smartest man in London, and for daring I am not sure that he has not a claim to be third. I have known something of him before.’*  

*‘Evidently,’ said I, ‘Mr. Wilson’s assistant counts for a good deal in this mystery of the Red-Headed League. I am sure that you inquired your way merely in order that you might see him.’*  

*‘Not him.’*  

*‘What then?’*  

*‘The knees of his trousers.’*  

*‘And what did you see?’*

*‘That, Watson,’ said he, ‘is one of the most interesting establishments in London. It is the Coburg branch of the City and Suburban Bank. I have a little problem to solve inside those walls, and I think that we shall have time for it before lunch.’*  

*He then entered the bank, and I followed him. He presented a card to the manager, and in a few moments we were admitted into a private room, where we were joined by that functionary, a tall, pale, clean-shaven man of about forty, who received us with an air of frigid politeness.*  

*‘I presume, Mr. Holmes,’ said he, ‘that you have come about the business of Mr. Hosmer Angel?’*  

*‘Precisely.’*  

*‘We have made every inquiry, and we have been unable to find any trace of him. He left his lodgings in the morning, and he has not been heard of since.’*  

*‘How long ago was that?’*  

*‘Nearly two months.’*  

*‘And you have heard nothing?’*  

*‘Nothing.’*  

*‘And you have no theory?’*  

*‘None whatever.’*  

*‘I suppose that you have not ceased to look for him?’*  

*‘On the contrary, we have offered a reward of fifty pounds for any information which may lead to his recovery.’*  

*‘That was very liberal, I am sure. I should like to see the advertisement.’*  

*The manager took a paper from his desk and handed it to Holmes. It was as follows:—*

events.title: Applying for the Red-Headed League Position
detailed_summary: Wilson recounts how Spaulding brought the newspaper advertisement to his attention eight weeks prior, wishing he were red-headed himself.
Spaulding explained the League offered a fortune for little work and implied vacancies outnumbered qualified applicants.
Wilson, being largely homebound due to his business, was unaware of the League and asked for details.
Spaulding expressed surprise at Wilson's ignorance, pointing out Wilson's own eligibility.
He estimated the position paid a couple hundred pounds a year with minimal interference with other work.
Wilson, whose business was struggling, became interested in the extra income.

Spaulding elaborated, based on the ad, that the League was founded by a peculiar American millionaire, Ezekiah Hopkins, who sympathized with red-headed men and left his fortune to provide them easy jobs.
Wilson worried about immense competition, but Spaulding claimed it was limited to Londoners and men with truly fiery red hair, suggesting Wilson would easily qualify.
Confident in his hair color and spurred by Spaulding's knowledge, Wilson closed his shop for the day and went with Spaulding to the address.
Wilson describes an astonishing scene: Fleet Street packed with red-headed men of every shade responding to the ad.
Despite Wilson's despair at the competition, Spaulding energetically pushed him through the crowd to the office entrance.
They joined the flow of hopeful applicants going up the stairs and dejected ones coming down, eventually reaching the office.

“The first thing that put us out was that advertisement. Spaulding, he came down into the office just this day eight weeks, with this very paper in his hand, and he says:
“‘I wish to the Lord, Mr. Wilson, that I was a red-headed man.’
“‘Why that?’ I asks.
“‘Why,’ says he, ‘here’s another vacancy on the League of the Red-headed Men. It’s worth quite a little fortune to any man who gets it, and I understand that there are more vacancies than there are men, so that the trustees are at their wits’ end what to do with the money. If my hair would only change colour, here’s a nice little crib all ready for me to step into.’
“‘Why, what is it, then?’ I asked. You see, Mr. Holmes, I am a very stay-at-home man, and as my business came to me instead of my having to go to it, I was often weeks on end without putting my foot over the door-mat. In that way I didn’t know much of what was going on outside, and I was always glad of a bit of news.
“‘Have you never heard of the League of the Red-headed Men?’ he asked with his eyes open.
“‘Never.’
“‘Why, I wonder at that, for you are eligible yourself for one of the vacancies.’
“‘And what are they worth?’ I asked.
“‘Oh, merely a couple of hundred a year, but the work is slight, and it need not interfere very much with one’s other occupations.’
“Well, you can easily think that that made me prick up my ears, for the business has not been over good for some years, and an extra couple of hundred would have been very handy.
“‘Tell me all about it,’ said I.
“‘Well,’ said he, showing me the advertisement, ‘you can see for yourself that the League has a vacancy, and there is the address where you should apply for particulars. As far as I can make out, the League was founded by an American millionaire, Ezekiah Hopkins, who was very peculiar in his ways. He was himself red-headed, and he had a great sympathy for all red-headed men; so, when he died, it was found that he had left his enormous fortune in the hands of trustees, with instructions to apply the interest to the providing of easy berths to men whose hair is of that colour. From all I hear it is splendid pay and very little to do.’
“‘But,’ said I, ‘there would be millions of red-headed men who would apply.’
“‘Not so many as you might think,’ he answered. ‘You see it is really confined to Londoners, and to grown men. This American had started from London when he was young, and he wanted to do the old town a good turn. Then, again, I have heard it is no use your applying if your hair is light red, or dark red, or anything but real bright, blazing, fiery red. Now, if you cared to apply, Mr. Wilson, you would just walk in; but perhaps it would hardly be worth your while to put yourself out of the way for the sake of a few hundred pounds.’
“Now, it is a fact, gentlemen, as you may see for yourselves, that my hair is of a very full and rich tint, so that it seemed to me that if there was to be any competition in the matter I stood as good a chance as any man that I had ever met. Vincent Spaulding seemed to know so much about it that I thought he might prove useful, so I just ordered him to put up the shutters for the day and to come right away with me. He was very willing to have a holiday, so we shut the business up and started off for the address that was given us in the advertisement.
“I never hope to see such a sight as that again, Mr. Holmes. From north, south, east, and west every man who had a shade of red in his hair had tramped into the city to answer the advertisement. Fleet Street was choked with red-headed folk, and Pope’s Court looked like a coster’s orange barrow. I should not have thought there were so many in the whole country as were brought together by that single advertisement. Every shade of colour they were—straw, lemon, orange, brick, Irish-setter, liver, clay; but, as Spaulding said, there were not many who had the real vivid flame-coloured tint. When I saw how many were waiting, I would have given it up in despair; but Spaulding would not hear of it. How he did it I could not imagine, but he pushed and pulled and butted until he got me through the crowd, and right up to the steps which led to the office. There was a double stream upon the stair, some going up in hope, and some coming back dejected; but we wedged in as well as we could and soon found ourselves in the office.”

Spangles wanted to know where the money was to come from. ‘Holmes,’ said he, ‘this is a serious business. We can’t afford to throw good money after bad.’ But I was convinced that the advertisement held the key to the mystery, and I was determined to follow it through.”

Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his chair, his fingers steepled beneath his chin, as he recounted the curious case that had begun with a seemingly innocuous notice in the morning paper. His keen eyes gleamed with the satisfaction of a puzzle solved, though the path to its resolution had been anything but straightforward.

“The advertisement in question,” Holmes continued, “appeared in the agony column of *The Daily Telegraph*. It read: ‘To the Gentleman who called upon me last evening—I shall be at home at six o’clock this evening. Urgent. Bring the papers.—J. Davenport, 13, Little Ryder Street.’ At first glance, it appeared unremarkable, a simple arrangement between two acquaintances. But there were peculiarities that caught my attention.”

Dr. Watson, seated across from his friend, listened intently, his notebook open on his knee. “What struck you as unusual about it, Holmes?” he inquired.

“Several things, Watson. First, the name ‘J. Davenport’ is uncommon enough to be memorable, yet I could recall no prominent figure by that name. Second, the address—Little Ryder Street—is a quiet, almost obscure thoroughfare, hardly the place one would expect for urgent business. And third, the phrasing—‘Bring the papers’—was vague yet oddly specific. It suggested a transaction of some importance, yet the wording was deliberately opaque.”

Holmes rose from his chair and paced the room, his mind retracing the steps of his investigation. “I decided to pay a visit to 13, Little Ryder Street myself. Upon arriving, I found the house to be a modest dwelling, its façade giving no hint of intrigue. I knocked, and the door was answered by a nervous-looking man of middle age, who introduced himself as Mr. Davenport. His manner was agitated, his eyes darting about as though he feared being observed.”

Watson scribbled a note. “Did he admit you?”

“After some hesitation, yes. Once inside, I revealed my identity and explained my interest in the advertisement. Davenport’s reaction was telling—he paled and stammered, clearly unprepared for my visit. He claimed the notice was a private matter, a misunderstanding, and urged me to leave. But I pressed him, Watson. I sensed there was more beneath the surface.”

Holmes paused, his gaze distant. “It was then that I noticed the faint but unmistakable scent of chemicals—chloroform, unless I was mistaken. The pieces began to fall into place. I confronted Davenport, and under the weight of my deductions, he broke down. He confessed that the advertisement was a ruse, part of a scheme to lure a man named Harold Winstanley to the house.”

“Winstanley?” Watson interjected. “The name is familiar.”

“It should be. Harold Winstanley is a junior clerk at the Foreign Office, a man with access to sensitive documents. Davenport, it transpired, was an agent of a foreign power, tasked with obtaining those papers. The advertisement was a coded message, instructing Winstanley to deliver the documents that evening. The reference to ‘the papers’ was no accident.”

Watson whistled softly. “A spy, then. But how did you connect the advertisement to Winstanley?”

“By tracing the sequence of events,” Holmes replied. “Winstanley had been seen in the company of a mysterious gentleman—Davenport—in the days preceding the advertisement. Their meetings were brief, furtive. I suspected coercion, and when I examined Winstanley’s lodgings, I found evidence of blackmail. Davenport had ensnared him, exploiting a youthful indiscretion to force his cooperation.”

“And the chloroform?”

“A precaution. Davenport intended to drug Winstanley after obtaining the papers, leaving him with no memory of the exchange. A neat solution, from his perspective—no loose ends.”

Watson shook his head in admiration. “But you intervened before the meeting could take place.”

“Indeed. With the help of Inspector Lestrade, we apprehended Davenport and recovered the documents before they could be passed on. Winstanley, though culpable, was more victim than villain. The Foreign Office dealt with him leniently, given the circumstances.”

Holmes returned to his chair, the firelight casting flickering shadows across his sharp features. “The case was a reminder, Watson, of how often the most mundane details conceal the gravest dangers. An advertisement in a newspaper—hardly the stuff of high drama, yet it nearly precipitated a diplomatic catastrophe.”

Watson closed his notebook. “And what became of Davenport?”

“He sits in a prison cell, awaiting trial. His employers, needless to say, have disavowed all knowledge of him.” Holmes allowed himself a small, satisfied smile. “Another thread of the criminal web severed, thanks to the power of observation and deduction.”

“Your experience has been a most entertaining one,” remarked Holmes as his client paused and refreshed his memory with a huge pinch of snuff. “Pray continue your very interesting statement.”
“There was nothing in the office but a couple of wooden chairs and a deal table, behind which sat a small man with a head that was even redder than mine. He said a few words to each candidate as he came up, and then he always managed to find some fault in them which would disqualify them. Getting a vacancy did not seem to be such a very easy matter, after all. However, when our turn came the little man was much more favourable to me than to any of the others, and he closed the door as we entered, so that he might have a private word with us.

events.title: The Copying Task and the League's Sudden Dissolution
detailed_summary: Wilson recounts his initial doubts after securing the job, suspecting a hoax due to the implausibility of the will and the simple task.
Spaulding tried to reassure him, but Wilson remained skeptical.
The next morning, Wilson decided to investigate, bought supplies, and went to Pope's Court.
To his surprise, everything was legitimate: the table was ready, and Duncan Ross was present to start him on his work copying the encyclopedia from 'A'.
Ross checked on him periodically at first, then less frequently, eventually not appearing at all.
Wilson diligently copied the encyclopedia daily from ten to two, never daring to leave, and filled nearly a shelf with his writings.
He received his payment of four gold sovereigns each Saturday.
After eight weeks of this routine, having worked through entries like Abbots, Archery, Armour, Architecture, and Attica, the situation abruptly ended.
That very morning, Wilson arrived to find the office door shut and locked.
A small cardboard sign was tacked to the door.
Wilson presents the cardboard sign to Holmes and Watson.

events.text_segment:
“Well, I thought over the matter all day, and by evening I was in low spirits again; for I had quite persuaded myself that the whole affair must be some great hoax or fraud, though what its object might be I could not imagine. It seemed altogether past belief that anyone could make such a will, or that they would pay such a sum for doing anything so simple as copying out the Encyclopædia Britannica. Vincent Spaulding did what he could to cheer me up, but by bedtime I had reasoned myself out of the whole thing. However, in the morning I determined to have a look at it anyhow, so I bought a penny bottle of ink, and with a quill-pen, and seven sheets of foolscap paper, I started off for Pope’s Court.
“Well, to my surprise and delight, everything was as right as possible. The table was set out ready for me, and Mr. Duncan Ross was there to see that I got fairly to work. He started me off upon the letter A, and then he left me; but he would drop in from time to time to see that all was right with me. At two o’clock he bade me good-day, complimented me upon the amount that I had written, and locked the door of the office after me.
“This went on day after day, Mr. Holmes, and on Saturday the manager came in and planked down four golden sovereigns for my week’s work. It was the same next week, and the same the week after. Every morning I was there at ten, and every afternoon I left at two. By degrees Mr. Duncan Ross took to coming in only once of a morning, and then, after a time, he did not come in at all. Still, of course, I never dared to leave the room for an instant, for I was not sure when he might come, and the billet was such a good one, and suited me so well, that I would not risk the loss of it.
“Eight weeks passed away like this, and I had written about Abbots and Archery and Armour and Architecture and Attica, and hoped with diligence that I might get on to the B’s before very long. It cost me something in foolscap, and I had pretty nearly filled a shelf with my writings. And then suddenly the whole business came to an end.”
“To an end?”
“Yes, sir. And no later than this morning. I went to my work as usual at ten o’clock, but the door was shut and locked, with a little square of cardboard hammered on to the middle of the panel with a tack. Here it is, and you can read for yourself.”

It seemed too elaborate a scheme merely to play a trick upon an unsuspecting man like myself. Yet, if it were genuine, what could be the meaning of such an extraordinary proposition? The more I pondered, the more bewildered I became.  

That night, I resolved to put the matter to the test. If it were indeed a hoax, I should soon discover it; if not—well, I dared not think too far ahead. The address given in the advertisement led me to a quiet street in the West End, where I found myself standing before a modest but respectable-looking house. My knock was answered by a grave-faced butler, who, upon hearing my name, ushered me inside without a word.  

The interior was dimly lit, the furnishings sparse but of good quality. A sense of solemnity hung in the air, as though the very walls were privy to secrets they dared not reveal. I was shown into a small study, where a gentleman of middle age, with sharp, penetrating eyes, rose to greet me.  

"Mr. Wilson, I presume?" he said, extending his hand.  

I nodded, my curiosity now thoroughly aroused. "You are the one who placed the advertisement?"  

"I am," he replied. "And I assure you, Mr. Wilson, this is no jest. The matter is of the utmost seriousness."  

He motioned for me to sit, and as I did so, he produced a document from a drawer in his desk. "Before we proceed further, I must ask for your absolute discretion. What I am about to reveal to you must never leave this room."  

I hesitated, but the gravity in his voice compelled me to agree. "You have my word."  

"Very well," he said, unfolding the paper. "What I am about to propose may seem extraordinary, but I assure you, it is entirely real. Your assistance is required in a matter of great delicacy—one that involves not only my own interests but those of the Crown itself."  

My heart quickened at his words. The Crown? What possible connection could I, a humble pawnbroker, have with affairs of state? Yet the man’s manner left no room for doubt. He was deadly serious.  

"Tell me," I said, leaning forward, "what is it you wish me to do?"  

He smiled faintly, as though he had anticipated my question. "All in good time, Mr. Wilson. First, I must be certain of your trustworthiness. There are tests—small but necessary—to ensure you are the right man for the task."  

And with that, the mystery deepened further, leaving me more intrigued than ever. What strange path had I stumbled upon? Only time would tell.

events.title: Investigation Attempts and Holmes Takes the Case
detailed_summary: The sign read: "THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED. October 9, 1890."
Holmes and Watson burst into laughter at the abrupt notice and Wilson's dismayed expression.
Wilson, offended, threatens to leave if they only intend to laugh.
Holmes reassures him, finding the case refreshingly unusual despite its comical aspect, and urges him to continue.
Wilson explains his confusion and subsequent actions: inquiring at neighboring offices (none knew of the League) and questioning the landlord.
The landlord had never heard of the Red-Headed League and didn't know Duncan Ross.
When Wilson described the red-headed man in Room 4, the landlord identified him as William Morris, a solicitor who rented the room temporarily and had moved out the previous day.
The landlord provided Morris's new address: 17 King Edward Street.
Wilson went there but found a manufactory of artificial knee-caps, where no one knew Morris or Ross.
He returned home and consulted Spaulding, who offered no help beyond suggesting Wilson wait for news by post.
Unwilling to lose the position without answers, Wilson sought Holmes's advice.
Holmes commends Wilson's decision, acknowledging the case's remarkableness and potential gravity beyond the lost income.
Wilson laments the loss of £4 per week.
Holmes points out Wilson has actually gained about £30 and encyclopedic knowledge, having no real grievance against the League.
Wilson insists he wants to understand the perpetrators and their motive for the apparent prank.
Holmes agrees to investigate and asks about Spaulding: he'd been with Wilson about a month before the ad, hired cheaply from a dozen applicants.
Wilson describes Spaulding: small, stout, quick, clean-shaven despite being around thirty, with a white acid splash on his forehead.
Holmes becomes excited, confirming his suspicion, and asks if Spaulding's ears are pierced.
Wilson confirms, recalling Spaulding claimed a gypsy pierced them.
Holmes falls into deep thought, confirms Spaulding is still there, and asks if the business ran smoothly during Wilson's absences (it did, being quiet in the mornings).
Holmes concludes the interview, promising an opinion in a day or two, by Monday.

He held up a piece of white cardboard about the size of a sheet of note-paper. It read in this fashion:
“THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED. October 9, 1890.”
Sherlock Holmes and I surveyed this curt announcement and the rueful face behind it, until the comical side of the affair so completely overtopped every other consideration that we both burst out into a roar of laughter.
“I cannot see that there is anything very funny,” cried our client, flushing up to the roots of his flaming head. “If you can do nothing better than laugh at me, I can go elsewhere.”
“No, no,” cried Holmes, shoving him back into the chair from which he had half risen. “I really wouldn’t miss your case for the world. It is most refreshingly unusual. But there is, if you will excuse my saying so, something just a little funny about it. Pray what steps did you take when you found the card upon the door?”
“I was staggered, sir. I did not know what to do. Then I called at the offices round, but none of them seemed to know anything about it. Finally, I went to the landlord, who is an accountant living on the ground floor, and I asked him if he could tell me what had become of the Red-headed League. He said that he had never heard of any such body. Then I asked him who Mr. Duncan Ross was. He answered that the name was new to him.
“‘Well,’ said I, ‘the gentleman at No. 4.’
“‘What, the red-headed man?’
“‘Yes.’
“‘Oh,’ said he, ‘his name was William Morris. He was a solicitor and was using my room as a temporary convenience until his new premises were ready. He moved out yesterday.’
“‘Where could I find him?’
“‘Oh, at his new offices. He did tell me the address. Yes, 17 King Edward Street, near St. Paul’s.’
“I started off, Mr. Holmes, but when I got to that address it was a manufactory of artificial knee-caps, and no one in it had ever heard of either Mr. William Morris or Mr. Duncan Ross.”
“And what did you do then?” asked Holmes.
“I went home to Saxe-Coburg Square, and I took the advice of my assistant. But he could not help me in any way. He could only say that if I waited I should hear by post. But that was not quite good enough, Mr. Holmes. I did not wish to lose such a place without a struggle, so, as I had heard that you were good enough to give advice to poor folk who were in need of it, I came right away to you.”
“And you did very wisely,” said Holmes. “Your case is an exceedingly remarkable one, and I shall be happy to look into it. From what you have told me I think that it is possible that graver issues hang from it than might at first sight appear.”
“Grave enough!” said Mr. Jabez Wilson. “Why, I have lost four pound a week.”
“As far as you are personally concerned,” remarked Holmes, “I do not see that you have any grievance against this extraordinary league. On the contrary, you are, as I understand, richer by some £ 30, to say nothing of the minute knowledge which you have gained on every subject which comes under the letter A. You have lost nothing by them.”
“No, sir. But I want to find out about them, and who they are, and what their object was in playing this prank—if it was a prank—upon me. It was a pretty expensive joke for them, for it cost them two and thirty pounds.”
“We shall endeavour to clear up these points for you. And, first, one or two questions, Mr. Wilson. This assistant of yours who first called your attention to the advertisement—how long had he been with you?”
“About a month then.”
“How did he come?”
“In answer to an advertisement.”
“Was he the only applicant?”
“No, I had a dozen.”
“Why did you pick him?”
“Because he was handy and would come cheap.”
“At half wages, in fact.”
“Yes.”
“What is he like, this Vincent Spaulding?”

He held up a piece of white cardboard about the size of a sheet of note-paper. It was blank on both sides, save for a single line of writing in the center, executed in a neat, precise hand. The words were simple, yet they carried an air of mystery that immediately piqued my interest.

"Observe, Watson," said Holmes, his keen eyes gleaming with that peculiar light which I had come to associate with the excitement of a fresh problem. "What do you make of this?"

I took the cardboard from him and examined it closely. The message read: *"The game is afoot. Midnight at the old mill."* There was no signature, no indication of the sender's identity. The paper itself was of ordinary quality, the sort one might purchase at any stationer's shop in London.

"It appears to be an invitation of some sort," I ventured. "Though rather cryptic in nature."

"Indeed," Holmes murmured, taking the card back and holding it up to the light. "The ink is fresh, the handwriting deliberate—someone wished to ensure this message was received clearly. But by whom? And for what purpose?"

I watched as he paced the length of our sitting room, his long fingers tracing the edge of the cardboard absently. "You found this just now?" I asked.

"On the doorstep," he replied. "Left there within the last half-hour, I should think. Mrs. Hudson heard no knock, no sound of footsteps. Whoever delivered it did so with remarkable stealth."

I frowned. "Then it must be someone who knows your habits—someone aware that you would notice such a thing."

Holmes nodded approvingly. "Precisely, Watson. And that narrows our field considerably. Few individuals would go to such lengths to secure my attention without revealing themselves."

"But why the secrecy?" I wondered aloud. "If they seek your assistance, why not simply call upon you directly?"

"Ah, therein lies the intrigue," Holmes said, a faint smile playing about his lips. "The choice of words—'the game is afoot'—suggests a mind familiar with my methods. The reference to midnight and the old mill implies urgency and perhaps danger. It is a challenge, Watson, and one I do not intend to ignore."

I felt a familiar thrill of anticipation. Holmes in pursuit of a mystery was a sight to behold, and I had no doubt that this seemingly innocuous scrap of cardboard would lead us into another of his remarkable adventures.

"Shall we go to the old mill, then?" I asked.

"Undoubtedly," Holmes replied. "But not without preparation. If our unknown correspondent has gone to such lengths to arrange this meeting, we must assume they are not without resources—or malice."

He moved to his chemical table and began assembling a small kit of vials and instruments, which he placed carefully into the pockets of his coat. I, in turn, fetched my revolver, checking its load before slipping it into my own pocket. One could never be too cautious when dealing with the unknown.

As the evening wore on, the fog that had been lingering all day thickened, casting eerie shadows across Baker Street. The gas lamps flickered weakly against the gloom, and the occasional clip-clop of a passing hansom cab seemed muffled, as though the very air conspired to shroud the city in secrecy.

At half-past eleven, we set out, Holmes leading the way with his usual purposeful stride. The old mill in question stood on the outskirts of London, a relic of the industrial age now fallen into disuse. It was a place frequented by vagrants and, if rumor were to be believed, by those with darker purposes.

The journey was a silent one, each of us lost in our own thoughts. I could not help but wonder what awaited us—a desperate plea for help, a trap, or something else entirely? Holmes, ever inscrutable, gave no indication of his own speculations.

At last, the looming silhouette of the mill came into view, its broken windows like sightless eyes staring out into the night. The creak of its weather-beaten timbers in the wind was the only sound to greet us as we approached.

Holmes paused at the entrance, his hand raised in caution. "Stay close, Watson," he whispered. "And keep your revolver at the ready."

With that, we stepped into the darkness beyond. The interior of the mill was a labyrinth of shadows, the faint moonlight filtering through the cracks in the walls providing only the barest illumination. The air was thick with dust and the scent of decay.

Then, from the depths of the building, came a sound—a soft, deliberate footstep. Holmes tensed beside me, his eyes scanning the blackness.

"Show yourself," he called, his voice steady and commanding.

For a moment, there was silence. Then, a match flared, casting a sudden glow that revealed a figure standing not ten feet from us. The face that emerged from the darkness was one I had never seen before—sharp-featured, with eyes that burned with an intensity that was almost unsettling.

"Mr. Holmes," the stranger said, his voice low and measured. "I had hoped you would come."

Holmes inclined his head slightly. "You have my attention. Now, perhaps you would care to explain this little drama?"

The man smiled, though there was no warmth in it. "All in good time. First, I must be certain you are alone."

"You have my word," Holmes replied coolly. "And my associate, Dr. Watson, is here by my invitation. If you have something to say, say it."

The stranger studied us for a long moment before nodding. "Very well. What I have to tell you concerns a matter of grave importance—one that touches upon the highest levels of government. But be warned, Mr. Holmes: once you hear what I have to say, there will be no turning back."

Holmes's eyes gleamed with interest. "I would have it no other way."

And so, beneath the crumbling roof of the old mill, with the fog pressing in around us like a living thing, the stranger began his tale—a tale that would lead us into one of the most dangerous and perplexing cases of my friend's illustrious career.

“Well, Watson,” said Holmes when our visitor had left us, “what do you make of it all?”
“I make nothing of it,” I answered frankly. “It is a most mysterious business.”
“As a rule,” said Holmes, “the more bizarre a thing is the less mysterious it proves to be. It is your commonplace, featureless crimes which are really puzzling, just as a commonplace face is the most difficult to identify. But I must be prompt over this matter.”
“What are you going to do, then?” I asked.
“To smoke,” he answered. “It is quite a three pipe problem, and I beg that you won’t speak to me for fifty minutes.” He curled himself up in his chair, with his thin knees drawn up to his hawk-like nose, and there he sat with his eyes closed and his black clay pipe thrusting out like the bill of some strange bird. I had come to the conclusion that he had dropped asleep, and indeed was nodding myself, when he suddenly sprang out of his chair with the gesture of a man who has made up his mind and put his pipe down upon the mantelpiece.
“Sarasate plays at the St. James’s Hall this afternoon,” he remarked. “What do you think, Watson? Could your patients spare you for a few hours?”
“I have nothing to do to-day. My practice is never very absorbing.”
“Then put on your hat and come. I am going through the City first, and we can have some lunch on the way. I observe that there is a good deal of German music on the programme, which is rather more to my taste than Italian or French. It is introspective, and I want to introspect. Come along!”
We travelled by the Underground as far as Aldersgate; and a short walk took us to Saxe-Coburg Square, the scene of the singular story which we had listened to in the morning. It was a poky, little, shabby-genteel place, where four lines of dingy two-storied brick houses looked out into a small railed-in enclosure, where a lawn of weedy grass and a few clumps of faded laurel bushes made a hard fight against a smoke-laden and uncongenial atmosphere. Three gilt balls and a brown board with “JABEZ WILSON” in white letters, upon a corner house, announced the place where our red-headed client carried on his business. Sherlock Holmes stopped in front of it with his head on one side and looked it all over, with his eyes shining brightly between puckered lids. Then he walked slowly up the street, and then down again to the corner, still looking keenly at the houses. Finally he returned to the pawnbroker’s, and, having thumped vigorously upon the pavement with his stick two or three times, he went up to the door and knocked. It was instantly opened by a bright-looking, clean-shaven young fellow, who asked him to step in.
“Thank you,” said Holmes, “I only wished to ask you how you would go from here to the Strand.”
“Third right, fourth left,” answered the assistant promptly, closing the door.
“Smart fellow, that,” observed Holmes as we walked away. “He is, in my judgment, the fourth smartest man in London, and for daring I am not sure that he has not a claim to be third. I have known something of him before.”
“Evidently,” said I, “Mr. Wilson’s assistant counts for a good deal in this mystery of the Red-headed League. I am sure that you inquired your way merely in order that you might see him.”
“Not him.”
“What then?”
“The knees of his trousers.”
“And what did you see?”
“What I expected to see.”
“Why did you beat the pavement?”
“My dear doctor, this is a time for observation, not for talk. We are spies in an enemy’s country. We know something of Saxe-Coburg Square. Let us now explore the parts which lie behind it.”
The road in which we found ourselves as we turned round the corner from the retired Saxe-Coburg Square presented as great a contrast to it as the front of a picture does to the back. It was one of the main arteries which conveyed the traffic of the City to the north and west. The roadway was blocked with the immense stream of commerce flowing in a double tide inward and outward, while the footpaths were black with the hurrying swarm of pedestrians. It was difficult to realise as we looked at the line of fine shops and stately business premises that they really abutted on the other side upon the faded and stagnant square which we had just quitted.
“Let me see,” said Holmes, standing at the corner and glancing along the line, “I should like just to remember the order of the houses here. It is a hobby of mine to have an exact knowledge of London. There is Mortimer’s, the tobacconist, the little newspaper shop, the Coburg branch of the City and Suburban Bank, the Vegetarian Restaurant, and McFarlane’s carriage-building depot. That carries us right on to the other block. And now, Doctor, we’ve done our work, so it’s time we had some play. A sandwich and a cup of coffee, and then off to violin-land, where all is sweetness and delicacy and harmony, and there are no red-headed clients to vex us with their conundrums.”

I confess I was somewhat puzzled by the case our visitor had just laid before us. The details were peculiar, to say the least, and I found myself turning them over in my mind without arriving at any satisfactory conclusion.  

“It is certainly a most singular affair,” I replied. “The idea of a man receiving a single orange pip through the post as a warning—and then meeting his death under mysterious circumstances—suggests some dark and hidden menace. Yet I cannot for the life of me see what connection there could be between the sending of such a token and the subsequent tragedy.”  

Holmes, who had been lounging in his chair with his eyes half-closed, now sat up with sudden energy. “Ah, Watson, you disappoint me! The connection is perfectly clear to the trained observer. Consider the facts as they were presented to us. Our client, young Openshaw, tells us that his uncle, Elias Openshaw, received a letter marked ‘K.K.K.’ containing nothing but a few dried orange pips. Shortly afterward, the uncle is found dead in a shallow pool near his house, the verdict being accidental drowning. Then, the father, Joseph Openshaw, receives a similar letter and meets an equally sudden and unexplained end. Now, young John Openshaw himself has received the same ominous warning. Surely you perceive the pattern?”  

I shook my head. “I see that there is a pattern, certainly, but I fail to understand its significance. What can these initials ‘K.K.K.’ mean, and why should they inspire such terror?”  

Holmes sprang to his feet and paced the room with his quick, nervous stride. “Watson, you have heard, no doubt, of the Ku Klux Klan?”  

“The American secret society? Yes, I have read something of it. A violent organization, if I remember rightly, which flourished in the Southern states after the Civil War.”  

“Precisely! The letters ‘K.K.K.’ are the unmistakable signature of that infamous body. The Ku Klux Klan was formed by ex-Confederate soldiers after the war, ostensibly to uphold the rights of the Southern whites, but in reality, it became a vehicle for terror and lawlessness. Its members were bound by oaths of secrecy and committed countless outrages against freed slaves and their sympathizers. The society was eventually suppressed, but not before it had left a legacy of fear and bloodshed.”  

“But what has this to do with the Openshaws?” I asked.  

“That is what we must determine. Elias Openshaw lived for many years in America, and it is clear that he incurred the enmity of this organization. The sending of the orange pips is a traditional method of warning among them—a signal that the recipient has been marked for death. The fact that both Elias and his brother Joseph met with sudden ends after receiving these warnings suggests that the Klan’s vengeance is implacable, even after so many years.”  

“But surely,” I protested, “if this is the work of the Ku Klux Klan, we are dealing with a matter beyond the scope of English law. The society was disbanded long ago, and its members scattered.”  

Holmes smiled grimly. “Disbanded, yes—but not extinct. There may yet be survivors who nurse old grudges. And remember, Watson, the Openshaws were not ordinary victims. Elias was a man of some prominence in Florida, and his return to England may have been seen as an attempt to escape retribution. The Klan does not forgive.”  

“Then you believe young John Openshaw is in real danger?”  

“Undoubtedly. The fact that he has received the same warning as his uncle and father leaves no room for doubt. The question is not whether he is in danger, but how we may avert it.”  

I was struck by the gravity of the situation. “What do you propose to do, Holmes?”  

“First, we must act swiftly. The interval between the receipt of the warning and the execution of the threat has been short in the previous cases. We must place young Openshaw under protection at once. Secondly, we must trace the origin of these letters. The postmarks may give us some clue as to the whereabouts of his enemies.”  

Holmes strode to his desk and began scribbling a telegram. “I shall instruct Lestrade to provide a guard for our client. In the meantime, Watson, I suggest you arm yourself. We may yet have need of your service revolver before this business is concluded.”  

I nodded, feeling the weight of responsibility settle upon me. There was something peculiarly sinister about this case—the cold, methodical nature of the threats, the shadowy figures of the past reaching out to claim their due.  

“Do you think there is any hope of saving him, Holmes?” I asked.  

My friend’s face was grave. “We shall do our utmost, Watson. But against an enemy as relentless as the Ku Klux Klan, even our best efforts may not be enough. The pips have been cast, and the dice are in the hands of fate.”  

With that ominous pronouncement, Holmes turned back to his papers, and I was left to ponder the dark and tangled web into which we had been drawn.

My friend was an enthusiastic musician, being himself not only a very capable performer but a composer of no ordinary merit. All the afternoon he sat in the stalls wrapped in the most perfect happiness, gently waving his long, thin fingers in time to the music, while his gently smiling face and his languid, dreamy eyes were as unlike those of Holmes the sleuth-hound, Holmes the relentless, keen-witted, ready-handed criminal agent, as it was possible to conceive. In his singular character the dual nature alternately asserted itself, and his extreme exactness and astuteness represented, as I have often thought, the reaction against the poetic and contemplative mood which occasionally predominated in him. The swing of his nature took him from extreme languor to devouring energy; and, as I knew well, he was never so truly formidable as when, for days on end, he had been lounging in his armchair amid his improvisations and his black-letter editions. Then it was that the lust of the chase would suddenly come upon him, and that his brilliant reasoning power would rise to the level of intuition, until those who were unacquainted with his methods would look askance at him as on a man whose knowledge was not that of other mortals. When I saw him that afternoon so enwrapped in the music at St. James’s Hall I felt that an evil time might be coming upon those whom he had set himself to hunt down.
“You want to go home, no doubt, Doctor,” he remarked as we emerged.
“Yes, it would be as well.”
“And I have some business to do which will take some hours. This business at Coburg Square is serious.”
“Why serious?”
“A considerable crime is in contemplation. I have every reason to believe that we shall be in time to stop it. But to-day being Saturday rather complicates matters. I shall want your help to-night.”
“At what time?”
“Ten will be early enough.”
“I shall be at Baker Street at ten.”
“Very well. And, I say, Doctor, there may be some little danger, so kindly put your army revolver in your pocket.” He waved his hand, turned on his heel, and disappeared in an instant among the crowd.
I trust that I am not more dense than my neighbours, but I was always oppressed with a sense of my own stupidity in my dealings with Sherlock Holmes. Here I had heard what he had heard, I had seen what he had seen, and yet from his words it was evident that he saw clearly not only what had happened but what was about to happen, while to me the whole business was still confused and grotesque. As I drove home to my house in Kensington I thought over it all, from the extraordinary story of the red-headed copier of the Encyclopædia down to the visit to Saxe-Coburg Square, and the ominous words with which he had parted from me. What was this nocturnal expedition, and why should I go armed? Where were we going, and what were we to do? I had the hint from Holmes that this smooth-faced pawnbroker’s assistant was a formidable man—a man who might play a deep game. I tried to puzzle it out, but gave it up in despair and set the matter aside until night should bring an explanation.
It was a quarter-past nine when I started from home and made my way across the Park, and so through Oxford Street to Baker Street. Two hansoms were standing at the door, and as I entered the passage I heard the sound of voices from above. On entering his room, I found Holmes in animated conversation with two men, one of whom I recognised as Peter Jones, the official police agent, while the other was a long, thin, sad-faced man, with a very shiny hat and oppressively respectable frock-coat.
“Ha! Our party is complete,” said Holmes, buttoning up his pea-jacket and taking his heavy hunting crop from the rack. “Watson, I think you know Mr. Jones, of Scotland Yard? Let me introduce you to Mr. Merryweather, who is to be our companion in to-night’s adventure.”
“We’re hunting in couples again, Doctor, you see,” said Jones in his consequential way. “Our friend here is a wonderful man for starting a chase. All he wants is an old dog to help him to do the running down.”
“I hope a wild goose may not prove to be the end of our chase,” observed Mr. Merryweather gloomily.
“You may place considerable confidence in Mr. Holmes, sir,” said the police agent loftily. “He has his own little methods, which are, if he won’t mind my saying so, just a little too theoretical and fantastic, but he has the makings of a detective in him. It is not too much to say that once or twice, as in that business of the Sholto murder and the Agra treasure, he has been more nearly correct than the official force.”
“Oh, if you say so, Mr. Jones, it is all right,” said the stranger with deference. “Still, I confess that I miss my rubber. It is the first Saturday night for seven-and-twenty years that I have not had my rubber.”
“I think you will find,” said Sherlock Holmes, “that you will play for a higher stake to-night than you have ever done yet, and that the play will be more exciting. For you, Mr. Merryweather, the stake will be some £ 30,000; and for you, Jones, it will be the man upon whom you wish to lay your hands.”
“John Clay, the murderer, thief, smasher, and forger. He’s a young man, Mr. Merryweather, but he is at the head of his profession, and I would rather have my bracelets on him than on any criminal in London. He’s a remarkable man, is young John Clay. His grandfather was a royal duke, and he himself has been to Eton and Oxford. His brain is as cunning as his fingers, and though we meet signs of him at every turn, we never know where to find the man himself. He’ll crack a crib in Scotland one week, and be raising money to build an orphanage in Cornwall the next. I’ve been on his track for years and have never set eyes on him yet.”
“I hope that I may have the pleasure of introducing you to-night. I’ve had one or two little turns also with Mr. John Clay, and I agree with you that he is at the head of his profession. It is past ten, however, and quite time that we started. If you two will take the first hansom, Watson and I will follow in the second.”
Sherlock Holmes was not very communicative during the long drive and lay back in the cab humming the tunes which he had heard in the afternoon. We rattled through an endless labyrinth of gas-lit streets until we emerged into Farrington Street.
“We are close there now,” my friend remarked. “This fellow Merryweather is a bank director, and personally interested in the matter. I thought it as well to have Jones with us also. He is not a bad fellow, though an absolute imbecile in his profession. He has one positive virtue. He is as brave as a bulldog and as tenacious as a lobster if he gets his claws upon anyone. Here we are, and they are waiting for us.”
We had reached the same crowded thoroughfare in which we had found ourselves in the morning. Our cabs were dismissed, and, following the guidance of Mr. Merryweather, we passed down a narrow passage and through a side door, which he opened for us. Within there was a small corridor, which ended in a very massive iron gate. This also was opened, and led down a flight of winding stone steps, which terminated at another formidable gate. Mr. Merryweather stopped to light a lantern, and then conducted us down a dark, earth-smelling passage, and so, after opening a third door, into a huge vault or cellar, which was piled all round with crates and massive boxes.
“You are not very vulnerable from above,” Holmes remarked as he held up the lantern and gazed about him.
“Nor from below,” said Mr. Merryweather, striking his stick upon the flags which lined the floor. “Why, dear me, it sounds quite hollow!” he remarked, looking up in surprise.
“I must really ask you to be a little more quiet!” said Holmes severely. “You have already imperilled the whole success of our expedition. Might I beg that you would have the goodness to sit down upon one of those boxes, and not to interfere?”
The solemn Mr. Merryweather perched himself upon a crate, with a very injured expression upon his face, while Holmes fell upon his knees upon the floor and, with the lantern and a magnifying lens, began to examine minutely the cracks between the stones. A few seconds sufficed to satisfy him, for he sprang to his feet again and put his glass in his pocket.
“We have at least an hour before us,” he remarked, “for they can hardly take any steps until the good pawnbroker is safely in bed. Then they will not lose a minute, for the sooner they do their work the longer time they will have for their escape. We are at present, Doctor—as no doubt you have divined—in the cellar of the City branch of one of the principal London banks. Mr. Merryweather is the chairman of directors, and he will explain to you that there are reasons why the more daring criminals of London should take a considerable interest in this cellar at present.”
“It is our French gold,” whispered the director. “We have had several warnings that an attempt might be made upon it.”
“Your French gold?”
“Yes. We had occasion some months ago to strengthen our resources and borrowed for that purpose 30,000 napoleons from the Bank of France. It has become known that we have never had occasion to unpack the money, and that it is still lying in our cellar. The crate upon which I sit contains 2,000 napoleons packed between layers of lead foil. Our reserve of bullion is much larger at present than is usually kept in a single branch office, and the directors have had misgivings upon the subject.”
“Which were very well justified,” observed Holmes. “And now it is time that we arranged our little plans. I expect that within an hour matters will come to a head. In the meantime Mr. Merryweather, we must put the screen over that dark lantern.”
“And sit in the dark?”
“I am afraid so. I had brought a pack of cards in my pocket, and I thought that, as we were a partie carrée, you might have your rubber after all. But I see that the enemy’s preparations have gone so far that we cannot risk the presence of a light. And, first of all, we must choose our positions. These are daring men, and though we shall take them at a disadvantage, they may do us some harm unless we are careful. I shall stand behind this crate, and do you conceal yourselves behind those. Then, when I flash a light upon them, close in swiftly. If they fire, Watson, have no compunction about shooting them down.”
I placed my revolver, cocked, upon the top of the wooden case behind which I crouched. Holmes shot the slide across the front of his lantern and left us in pitch darkness—such an absolute darkness as I have never before experienced. The smell of hot metal remained to assure us that the light was still there, ready to flash out at a moment’s notice. To me, with my nerves worked up to a pitch of expectancy, there was something depressing and subduing in the sudden gloom, and in the cold dank air of the vault.
“They have but one retreat,” whispered Holmes. “That is back through the house into Saxe-Coburg Square. I hope that you have done what I asked you, Jones?”
“I have an inspector and two officers waiting at the front door.”
“Then we have stopped all the holes. And now we must be silent and wait.”

*‘You want to go home, no doubt, Doctor,’ he remarked as we emerged. ‘Yes; it would be as well.’*  

*‘And I have some business to do which will take some hours. This business at Coburg Square is serious.’*  

*‘Why serious?’*  

*‘A considerable crime is in contemplation. I have every reason to believe that we shall be in time to stop it. But to-day being Saturday rather complicates matters. I shall want your help to-night.’*  

*‘At what time?’*  

*‘Ten will be early enough.’*  

*‘I shall be at Baker Street at ten.’*  

*‘Very well. And, I say, Doctor, there may be some little danger, so kindly put your army revolver in your pocket.’ He waved his hand, turned on his heel, and disappeared in an instant among the crowd.*  

*I trust that I am not more dense than my neighbours, but I was always oppressed with a sense of my own stupidity in my dealings with Sherlock Holmes. Here I had heard what he had heard, I had seen what he had seen, and yet from his words it was evident that he saw clearly not only what had happened but what was about to happen, while to me the whole business was still confused and grotesque. As I drove home to my house in Kensington I thought over it all, from the extraordinary story of the red-headed copier of the Encyclopædia down to the visit to Saxe-Coburg Square, and the ominous words with which he had parted from me. I had the hint from Holmes that this smooth-faced pawnbroker’s assistant was a formidable man—a man who might play a deep game. I tried to puzzle it out, but gave it up in despair and set the matter aside until night should bring an explanation.*  

*It was a quarter-past nine when I started from home and made my way across the Park, and so through Oxford Street to Baker Street. Two hansoms were standing at the door, and as I entered the passage I heard the sound of voices from above. On entering his room I found Holmes in animated conversation with two men, one of whom I recognized as Peter Jones, the official police agent, while the other was a long, thin, sad-faced man, with a very shiny hat and oppressively respectable frock-coat.*  

*‘Ha! our party is complete,’ said Holmes, buttoning up his pea-jacket and taking his heavy hunting crop from the rack. ‘Watson, I think you know Mr. Jones, of Scotland Yard? Let me introduce you to Mr. Merryweather, who is to be our companion in to-night’s adventure.’*  

*‘We’re hunting in couples again, Doctor, you see,’ said Jones in his consequential way. ‘Our friend here is a wonderful man for starting a chase. All he wants is an old dog to help him to do the running down.’*  

*‘I hope a wild goose may not prove to be the end of our chase,’ observed Mr. Merryweather gloomily.*  

*‘You may place considerable confidence in Mr. Holmes, sir,’ said the police agent loftily. ‘He has his own little methods, which are, if he won’t mind my saying so, just a little too theoretical and fantastic, but he has the makings of a detective in him. *‘Oh, if you say so, Mr. Jones, it is all right,’ said the stranger with deference. ‘Still, I confess that I miss my rubber. It is the first Saturday night for seven-and-twenty years that I have not had my rubber.’*

*‘John Clay, the murderer, thief, smasher, and forger. He’s a young man, Mr. Merryweather, but he is at the head of his profession, and I would rather have my bracelets on him than on any criminal in London. He’s a remarkable man, is young John Clay. **The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes: A Musical Interlude**  

My friend was an enthusiastic musician, being himself not only a very capable performer but a composer of no ordinary merit. It was one of those rare evenings when Holmes, having concluded a particularly taxing case, allowed himself the luxury of relaxation. The strains of a violin filled the air of our Baker Street lodgings, a melancholic yet intricate melody that seemed to weave through the very fabric of the room.  

I had often remarked upon Holmes’s extraordinary talent with the instrument, a skill that seemed almost at odds with his otherwise coldly analytical nature. Yet, as I sat in my armchair, pipe in hand, I could not help but feel that the music revealed a side of him seldom seen—a depth of emotion and creativity that lay beneath the surface of his relentless logic.  

“That is a new composition, is it not?” I ventured, as the final notes faded into silence.  

Holmes turned to me, his sharp eyes gleaming with satisfaction. “Indeed, Watson. A little experiment in counterpoint. I find that the structure of music often mirrors the patterns of human thought—order emerging from chaos, themes recurring in unexpected ways.”  

“Much like your deductions,” I observed.  

He smiled faintly. “Precisely. Though I fear my musical efforts are but a poor imitation of the great masters.”  

I protested at once. “Nonsense, Holmes! Your playing is exceptional. I have heard many a professional violinist who could not match your skill.”  

He waved a dismissive hand. “Flattery, my dear Watson, though I appreciate the sentiment. But tell me—have you ever considered the parallels between music and crime?”  

I blinked in surprise. “I cannot say that I have.”  

Holmes leaned forward, his fingers steepled beneath his chin. “Consider this: a melody is constructed note by note, each one dependent upon the last, building toward a resolution. A criminal act is much the same—a series of actions, each leading inevitably to the final outcome. The key to solving a mystery, then, is to discern the underlying harmony, the hidden rhythm that connects each clue.”  

I chuckled. “You make it sound as though crime were an art form.”  

“And is it not?” Holmes countered. “The criminal, like the composer, must arrange his elements with care, lest the entire structure collapse. The difference, of course, is that one seeks to create beauty, while the other seeks to conceal ugliness.”  

I pondered this for a moment. “Then by your reasoning, a detective must be something of a musician himself—listening for the discordant notes that betray the criminal’s hand.”  

Holmes’s eyes sparkled with approval. “An apt analogy, Watson! You have a knack for grasping my meaning, even when I express myself in the most abstract terms.”  

At that moment, Mrs. Hudson entered with a tray of tea, her presence breaking the spell of our conversation. As she set the tray upon the table, she cast a fond glance at Holmes’s violin. “Always a pleasure to hear you play, Mr. Holmes. It brightens the whole house.”  

Holmes inclined his head. “You are too kind, Mrs. Hudson. Though I fear my nocturnal practices may sometimes disturb your rest.”  

She laughed. “Not at all! I’d rather hear your music than the sound of clients tramping up the stairs at all hours.”  

Once she had departed, I poured the tea, and we lapsed into a comfortable silence. The fire crackled in the hearth, casting flickering shadows upon the walls. Holmes, ever restless, soon took up his violin once more, this time playing a lively air that seemed to chase away the lingering solemnity of his earlier composition.  

As I listened, I reflected upon the many facets of my friend’s character. To the world, he was the consummate detective, a man of unerring logic and razor-sharp intellect. But in moments like these, I was privileged to see the artist within—the man who found solace in music, who understood the human heart as deeply as he understood the mechanisms of crime.  

“You should perform publicly,” I said impulsively. “I am certain you would be met with acclaim.”  

Holmes shook his head, his expression wry. “No, Watson. My music is for myself alone—and for those few, like you, who are kind enough to indulge me.”  

“Then I count myself fortunate indeed,” I replied sincerely.  

He played on, the notes dancing through the air like sparks from the fire. And for that evening, at least, the great detective set aside the puzzles of the criminal world and lost himself in the purer mysteries of melody and harmony.  

**Epilogue: A Case in C Minor**  

It was not long after this musical interlude that Holmes’s unique perspective on the relationship between crime and composition was put to the test. A most perplexing case came to our door—one that would challenge even his formidable intellect.  

A renowned conductor, Sir Edward Vane, had been receiving a series of anonymous letters, each containing a fragment of sheet music. The notes, when played, formed a haunting and disjointed tune that seemed to hold some hidden meaning. Sir Edward, a man of nerves already frayed by the pressures of his profession, was convinced that the messages were a prelude to some sinister act.  

Holmes, intrigued by the musical element of the mystery, took up the case with relish. For days, he pored over the fragments, playing them upon his violin, transposing them into different keys, searching for the pattern that eluded him.  

“It is a cipher,” he muttered one evening, his brow furrowed in concentration. “The notes themselves are the code. But to what end?”  

At last, the breakthrough came. Holmes, in a moment of inspiration, realized that the melody, when played backward, revealed a name—that of a disgraced former violinist whom Sir Edward had dismissed from his orchestra years before.  

“Revenge,” Holmes declared. “The man seeks to unsettle Sir Edward before striking. We must act at once.”  

And so we did, arriving at the conductor’s home just in time to prevent an attempted poisoning. The would-be assassin, driven by years of bitterness, was apprehended, and Sir Edward was left unharmed—though deeply shaken.  

As we returned to Baker Street, Holmes was uncharacteristically quiet. At length, he spoke.  

“There is a dark poetry to it, Watson. A man’s life ruined by music, and nearly ended by it as well.”  

I nodded. “Yet it was music, and your understanding of it, that saved him.”  

Holmes smiled faintly. “A fitting symmetry, is it not?”  

And with that, he took up his violin once more, as if to cleanse the air of the evening’s darkness with a sweeter, purer strain.  

Thus ended another chapter in the extraordinary career of Sherlock Holmes—a man whose genius knew no bounds, whether applied to the science of detection or the art of music. And I, as ever, remained his most devoted chronicler and friend.
