The pipe was still between his lips, the smoke still curled upward, and the room was full of a dense tobacco haze, but nothing remained of the heap of shag which I had seen upon the previous night. Holmes sat motionless in his armchair, his eyes half-closed, his mind evidently far away from the confines of our humble sitting-room in Baker Street. I had long since grown accustomed to these moods of intense concentration, and so I made no attempt to disturb him, instead turning my attention to the morning paper.  

Yet, as I scanned the headlines, my thoughts kept returning to the singular case we had been engaged in—the disappearance of the blue carbuncle, that rare and valuable gemstone which had vanished from the Countess of Morcar’s hotel suite under the most mysterious circumstances. The police had been baffled, and it was only through Holmes’s extraordinary powers of deduction that we had traced the stone to the possession of an innocent man, a humble commissionaire named Peterson.  

But now, the case seemed to have reached an impasse. The stone had been recovered, yet the true thief remained at large. Holmes had spent the entire night pacing the room, muttering to himself, and filling the air with the thick fumes of his strongest tobacco. I had retired to bed, leaving him to his meditations, and now, upon rising, I found him in the same position, the same cloud of smoke hanging about him like a spectral shroud.  

At last, he stirred. His keen grey eyes flickered open, and he fixed me with a penetrating gaze.  

“Watson,” he said abruptly, “have you ever considered the psychology of a thief?”  

I laid aside my newspaper. “I cannot say that I have given it much thought,” I admitted.  

“A fascinating study,” Holmes mused, leaning forward to tap the ashes from his pipe into the hearth. “The criminal mind operates under a peculiar set of compulsions. Some steal out of necessity, others for the thrill of it. But the theft of the blue carbuncle—ah, that was no ordinary crime.”  

“You believe the thief had a particular motive?”  

“Undoubtedly. The stone was taken not for its monetary value, but for what it represented. The Countess of Morcar is a woman of considerable influence, and the carbuncle was a symbol of her power. Its disappearance was intended as a blow to her pride.”  

I frowned. “But who would dare such a thing?”  

Holmes’s lips curled into a thin smile. “Someone who knew her intimately. Someone who had been wronged by her in the past. And that, my dear Watson, narrows our field considerably.”  

He rose from his chair and crossed to the window, drawing back the curtain to let in the pale morning light. Outside, the streets of London were already bustling with activity—carriages rattling past, newsboys crying the latest headlines, and the occasional shrill whistle of a policeman directing traffic.  

“I have sent a telegram to Inspector Bradstreet,” Holmes continued. “There is a certain individual I wish to question—a man with a grudge against the Countess, and the cunning to carry out such a theft.”  

“You have a suspect?”  

“I do. But I shall say no more until I have gathered further evidence. In the meantime, Watson, I suggest you fortify yourself with breakfast. I have a feeling today will be a most instructive day.”  

With that, he turned back to his pipe, refilling it with fresh tobacco from the Persian slipper where he kept his supply. The match flared, and soon the room was once again filled with the familiar, comforting scent of his shag.  

I could not help but marvel at the man. While others might have been content to rest on their laurels after recovering the stolen gem, Holmes was driven by an insatiable curiosity, a need to uncover every last thread of the mystery. It was this relentless pursuit of truth that made him the greatest detective of our age.  

As I rang for Mrs. Hudson to bring up our breakfast, I reflected that, once again, I was about to witness the master at work. And though I had chronicled many of his cases before, I knew that this one, too, would be a tale worth telling.  

For where Sherlock Holmes was concerned, the game was always afoot.

events.title: Watson's Christmas Visit and the Mysterious Hat
detailed_summary: Dr. Watson visits Sherlock Holmes shortly after Christmas.
Holmes is found examining a worn-out felt hat.
Holmes assures Watson he isn't interrupting and finds the hat an interesting, though trivial, intellectual problem.
Watson assumes the hat is linked to a serious crime.
Holmes corrects him, explaining it's merely a minor incident arising from the dense population of London, similar to some previous non-criminal cases.
Holmes reveals the hat belongs to an unknown man and was found by Peterson, the commissionaire, along with a goose on Christmas morning.

He recounts Peterson's story: Peterson witnessed a tall man carrying a goose get into a fight with roughs, accidentally break a shop window, and flee upon Peterson's approach, dropping both hat and goose.
The goose had a card reading 'For Mrs. Henry Baker', and the hat lining had the initials 'H. B.', but identifying the owner among many Henry Bakers proved difficult.
Peterson brought both items to Holmes.
The goose was kept until that morning, when Peterson took it home to cook before it spoiled, leaving Holmes with only the hat.

I had called upon my friend Sherlock Holmes upon the second morning after Christmas, with the intention of wishing him the compliments of the season. He was lounging upon the sofa in a purple dressing-gown, a pipe-rack within his reach upon the right, and a pile of crumpled morning papers, evidently newly studied, near at hand. Beside the couch was a wooden chair, and on the angle of the back hung a very seedy and disreputable hard-felt hat, much the worse for wear, and cracked in several places. A lens and a forceps lying upon the seat of the chair suggested that the hat had been suspended in this manner for the purpose of examination.
“You are engaged,” said I; “perhaps I interrupt you.”
“Not at all. I am glad to have a friend with whom I can discuss my results. The matter is a perfectly trivial one”—he jerked his thumb in the direction of the old hat—“but there are points in connection with it which are not entirely devoid of interest and even of instruction.”
I seated myself in his armchair and warmed my hands before his crackling fire, for a sharp frost had set in, and the windows were thick with the ice crystals. “I suppose,” I remarked, “that, homely as it looks, this thing has some deadly story linked on to it—that it is the clue which will guide you in the solution of some mystery and the punishment of some crime.”
“No, no. No crime,” said Sherlock Holmes, laughing. “Only one of those whimsical little incidents which will happen when you have four million human beings all jostling each other within the space of a few square miles. Amid the action and reaction of so dense a swarm of humanity, every possible combination of events may be expected to take place, and many a little problem will be presented which may be striking and bizarre without being criminal. We have already had experience of such.”
“So much so,” I remarked, “that of the last six cases which I have added to my notes, three have been entirely free of any legal crime.”
“Precisely. You allude to my attempt to recover the Irene Adler papers, to the singular case of Miss Mary Sutherland, and to the adventure of the man with the twisted lip. Well, I have no doubt that this small matter will fall into the same innocent category. You know Peterson, the commissionaire?”
“Yes.”
“It is to him that this trophy belongs.”
“It is his hat.”
“No, no, he found it. Its owner is unknown. I beg that you will look upon it not as a battered billycock but as an intellectual problem. And, first, as to how it came here. It arrived upon Christmas morning, in company with a good fat goose, which is, I have no doubt, roasting at this moment in front of Peterson’s fire. The facts are these: about four o’clock on Christmas morning, Peterson, who, as you know, is a very honest fellow, was returning from some small jollification and was making his way homeward down Tottenham Court Road. In front of him he saw, in the gaslight, a tallish man, walking with a slight stagger, and carrying a white goose slung over his shoulder. As he reached the corner of Goodge Street, a row broke out between this stranger and a little knot of roughs. One of the latter knocked off the man’s hat, on which he raised his stick to defend himself and, swinging it over his head, smashed the shop window behind him. Peterson had rushed forward to protect the stranger from his assailants; but the man, shocked at having broken the window, and seeing an official-looking person in uniform rushing towards him, dropped his goose, took to his heels, and vanished amid the labyrinth of small streets which lie at the back of Tottenham Court Road. The roughs had also fled at the appearance of Peterson, so that he was left in possession of the field of battle, and also of the spoils of victory in the shape of this battered hat and a most unimpeachable Christmas goose.”
“Which surely he restored to their owner?”
“My dear fellow, there lies the problem. It is true that ‘For Mrs. Henry Baker’ was printed upon a small card which was tied to the bird’s left leg, and it is also true that the initials ‘H. B.’ are legible upon the lining of this hat, but as there are some thousands of Bakers, and some hundreds of Henry Bakers in this city of ours, it is not easy to restore lost property to any one of them.”
“What, then, did Peterson do?”
“He brought round both hat and goose to me on Christmas morning, knowing that even the smallest problems are of interest to me. The goose we retained until this morning, when there were signs that, in spite of the slight frost, it would be well that it should be eaten without unnecessary delay. Its finder has carried it off, therefore, to fulfil the ultimate destiny of a goose, while I continue to retain the hat of the unknown gentleman who lost his Christmas dinner.”

I had called upon my friend Sherlock Holmes upon the second morning after Christmas, with the intention of wishing him the compliments of the season. The weather was bitterly cold, and a thick fog hung over London, muffling the sounds of the city and casting an eerie stillness upon the streets. As I ascended the seventeen steps to our old lodgings at 221B Baker Street, I could not help but reflect on the many strange and remarkable cases we had shared within those familiar walls.

Upon entering, I found Holmes seated by the fire, his long, thin fingers steepled beneath his chin, his keen grey eyes fixed upon some unseen point in the distance. The room was in its usual state of comfortable disorder—papers strewn across the desk, chemical apparatus cluttering the mantelpiece, and a violin lying carelessly upon the sofa. Mrs. Hudson had evidently been in, for a cheerful fire crackled in the grate, and the aroma of freshly brewed coffee filled the air.

"Ah, Watson," Holmes said without turning, "I perceive by your step that you have been walking briskly, no doubt to ward off the chill. And that slight hesitation before you knocked suggests you were debating whether to disturb me. I assure you, your company is always welcome."

I smiled, accustomed as I was to his uncanny observations. "You are right, as usual, Holmes. I did not wish to interrupt if you were engaged in some important matter."

He waved a dismissive hand. "Nothing of consequence. Merely turning over a few trifling problems in my mind. But tell me, how fares the good Mrs. Watson? I trust she is well?"

"She is, thank you. She sends her regards and hopes you will join us for dinner soon."

Holmes nodded absently, his attention already drifting back to his thoughts. I took my usual chair and poured myself a cup of coffee, savoring its warmth. For a few moments, we sat in companionable silence, the only sound the occasional pop of the fire.

It was then that the doorbell rang, sharp and insistent. Holmes raised an eyebrow. "A client, and one in some haste, by the sound of it."

Mrs. Hudson soon appeared, ushering in a young woman whose pale face and trembling hands spoke of deep distress. She was fashionably dressed, but her clothes were disheveled, as though she had dressed in great haste. Her eyes, wide with fear, darted about the room before settling on Holmes.

"Mr. Holmes," she gasped, "I beg your assistance. I fear something terrible has happened—something I cannot explain."

Holmes rose swiftly and guided her to a chair. "Pray compose yourself, madam, and tell us what has brought you here in such a state. This is my friend and colleague, Dr. Watson. You may speak freely before him."

The woman took a shuddering breath. "My name is Miss Violet Hunter. Last night, my employer, Mr. Rucastle of the Copper Beeches, received a most alarming telegram. He became quite agitated and left the house immediately, saying he would return by morning. But he has not come back, and this morning, I found—" She broke off, her voice failing her.

"Found what, Miss Hunter?" Holmes prompted gently.

"I found his study in disarray, and on his desk... a single white feather, stained with blood."

Holmes leaned forward, his eyes alight with interest. "A white feather, you say? And this Mr. Rucastle—what is his profession?"

"He is a retired colonel, recently returned from India. He spoke little of his past, but I gathered he had seen much hardship there."

Holmes exchanged a glance with me. "Watson, this grows more intriguing by the moment. Miss Hunter, can you tell us anything more of this telegram?"

She shook her head. "I saw only that it bore a foreign stamp. Mr. Rucastle read it, turned quite pale, and left at once."

Holmes sprang to his feet. "Then we must act quickly. Watson, fetch your service revolver. Miss Hunter, would you be so kind as to take us to the Copper Beeches at once?"

Within the hour, we were rattling through the fog-shrouded countryside in a hansom cab, Miss Hunter sitting opposite us, her hands clenched tightly in her lap. Holmes spent the journey questioning her closely about the household, the servants, and any peculiarities she had observed in Mr. Rucastle's behavior.

As we neared the isolated manor house, the fog grew denser, wrapping the gabled roof and ancient copper beeches in a ghostly shroud. The place had an air of melancholy about it, as though it held secrets too grim to speak aloud.

The butler, a gaunt man with a perpetual frown, admitted us with obvious reluctance. Holmes wasted no time in examining the study, his sharp eyes missing nothing—the overturned chair, the scattered papers, the bloodstained feather lying ominously on the blotter.

"Ah," he murmured, picking up the feather with tweezers from his pocket. "This is no ordinary feather, Watson. Note the distinctive markings. It is from a rare species of Himalayan vulture, often associated with certain... esoteric practices in the East."

Miss Hunter gasped. "Then you think—"

"I think, my dear lady, that your employer has fallen victim to a vendetta that began far from these shores. But fear not; we shall get to the bottom of it."

And with that, Sherlock Holmes, the greatest detective of his age, set to work unraveling the mystery of the bloodstained feather and the vanished colonel—a mystery that would lead us into the darkest corners of human nature and test the limits of even his remarkable intellect.

events.text_segment:
“Did he not advertise?”
“No.”
“Then, what clue could you have as to his identity?”
“Only as much as we can deduce.”
“From his hat?”
“Precisely.”
“But you are joking. What can you gather from this old battered felt?”
“Here is my lens. You know my methods. What can you gather yourself as to the individuality of the man who has worn this article?”
I took the tattered object in my hands and turned it over rather ruefully. It was a very ordinary black hat of the usual round shape, hard and much the worse for wear. The lining had been of red silk, but was a good deal discoloured. There was no maker’s name; but, as Holmes had remarked, the initials “H. B.” were scrawled upon one side. It was pierced in the brim for a hat-securer, but the elastic was missing. For the rest, it was cracked, exceedingly dusty, and spotted in several places, although there seemed to have been some attempt to hide the discoloured patches by smearing them with ink.
“I can see nothing,” said I, handing it back to my friend.
“On the contrary, Watson, you can see everything. You fail, however, to reason from what you see. You are too timid in drawing your inferences.”
“Then, pray tell me what it is that you can infer from this hat?”
He picked it up and gazed at it in the peculiar introspective fashion which was characteristic of him. “It is perhaps less suggestive than it might have been,” he remarked, “and yet there are a few inferences which are very distinct, and a few others which represent at least a strong balance of probability. That the man was highly intellectual is of course obvious upon the face of it, and also that he was fairly well-to-do within the last three years, although he has now fallen upon evil days. He had foresight, but has less now than formerly, pointing to a moral retrogression, which, when taken with the decline of his fortunes, seems to indicate some evil influence, probably drink, at work upon him. This may account also for the obvious fact that his wife has ceased to love him.”
“My dear Holmes!”
“He has, however, retained some degree of self-respect,” he continued, disregarding my remonstrance. “He is a man who leads a sedentary life, goes out little, is out of training entirely, is middle-aged, has grizzled hair which he has had cut within the last few days, and which he anoints with lime-cream. These are the more patent facts which are to be deduced from his hat. Also, by the way, that it is extremely improbable that he has gas laid on in his house.”
“You are certainly joking, Holmes.”
“Not in the least. Is it possible that even now, when I give you these results, you are unable to see how they are attained?”
“I have no doubt that I am very stupid, but I must confess that I am unable to follow you. For example, how did you deduce that this man was intellectual?”
For answer Holmes clapped the hat upon his head. It came right over the forehead and settled upon the bridge of his nose. “It is a question of cubic capacity,” said he; “a man with so large a brain must have something in it.”
“The decline of his fortunes, then?”
“This hat is three years old. These flat brims curled at the edge came in then. It is a hat of the very best quality. Look at the band of ribbed silk and the excellent lining. If this man could afford to buy so expensive a hat three years ago, and has had no hat since, then he has assuredly gone down in the world.”
“Well, that is clear enough, certainly. But how about the foresight and the moral retrogression?”
Sherlock Holmes laughed. “Here is the foresight,” said he putting his finger upon the little disc and loop of the hat-securer. “They are never sold upon hats. If this man ordered one, it is a sign of a certain amount of foresight, since he went out of his way to take this precaution against the wind. But since we see that he has broken the elastic and has not troubled to replace it, it is obvious that he has less foresight now than formerly, which is a distinct proof of a weakening nature. On the other hand, he has endeavoured to conceal some of these stains upon the felt by daubing them with ink, which is a sign that he has not entirely lost his self-respect.”
“Your reasoning is certainly plausible.”
“The further points, that he is middle-aged, that his hair is grizzled, that it has been recently cut, and that he uses lime-cream, are all to be gathered from a close examination of the lower part of the lining. The lens discloses a large number of hair-ends, clean cut by the scissors of the barber. They all appear to be adhesive, and there is a distinct odour of lime-cream. This dust, you will observe, is not the gritty, grey dust of the street but the fluffy brown dust of the house, showing that it has been hung up indoors most of the time, while the marks of moisture upon the inside are proof positive that the wearer perspired very freely, and could therefore, hardly be in the best of training.”
“But his wife—you said that she had ceased to love him.”
“This hat has not been brushed for weeks. When I see you, my dear Watson, with a week’s accumulation of dust upon your hat, and when your wife allows you to go out in such a state, I shall fear that you also have been unfortunate enough to lose your wife’s affection.”
“But he might be a bachelor.”
“Nay, he was bringing home the goose as a peace-offering to his wife. Remember the card upon the bird’s leg.”
“You have an answer to everything. But how on earth do you deduce that the gas is not laid on in his house?”
“One tallow stain, or even two, might come by chance; but when I see no less than five, I think that there can be little doubt that the individual must be brought into frequent contact with burning tallow—walks upstairs at night probably with his hat in one hand and a guttering candle in the other. Anyhow, he never got tallow-stains from a gas-jet. Are you satisfied?”
“Well, it is very ingenious,” said I, laughing; “but since, as you said just now, there has been no crime committed, and no harm done save the loss of a goose, all this seems to be rather a waste of energy.”
Sherlock Holmes had opened his mouth to reply, when the door flew open, and Peterson, the commissionaire, rushed into the apartment with flushed cheeks and the face of a man who is dazed with astonishment.

“Did he not advertise?” I asked, recalling the peculiar circumstances surrounding the case of the Red-Headed League.  

Holmes chuckled, his keen eyes alight with amusement. “Ah, Watson, you have hit upon the very heart of the matter. Indeed, he did advertise—most conspicuously, in fact. But therein lies the genius of the scheme.”  

I leaned forward in my chair, eager to hear his reasoning. The case had puzzled me greatly, for it seemed at first glance to be nothing more than a bizarre and inexplicable prank. Yet, as always, Holmes had seen through the deception with his usual clarity.  

“Consider the facts,” he continued, lighting his pipe with deliberate care. “Jabez Wilson, a pawnbroker of modest means, is approached by an agent of the so-called ‘Red-Headed League’ with an offer too good to refuse—a sinecure requiring nothing more than the copying of the Encyclopædia Britannica for four hours a day at a handsome salary. The only qualification? That he must have flaming red hair.”  

“A most singular condition,” I remarked.  

“Precisely! And one designed to ensure that only a very specific individual would apply. The advertisement was not meant to attract a multitude of candidates—it was tailored for Wilson alone.”  

“But why?” I pressed.  

Holmes exhaled a thin stream of smoke before replying. “Because the entire affair was a ruse, Watson—an elaborate distraction to keep Wilson away from his shop for several hours each day. While he dutifully copied out entries on ‘Abbey’ and ‘Archery,’ his assistant, the cunning Vincent Spaulding—or rather, John Clay, the notorious criminal—was hard at work tunneling from the cellar of Wilson’s establishment into the vault of the City and Suburban Bank next door.”  

I gasped as the full implications of the scheme became clear. “Then the advertisement was merely a means to an end!”  

“Exactly. Clay, a man of considerable intelligence and audacity, recognized that Wilson’s shop provided the perfect access point for his burglary. But he needed Wilson out of the way at regular intervals to carry out his excavation undisturbed. What better method than to invent a preposterous yet enticing occupation that would lure the pawnbroker away without arousing suspicion?”  

“But why red hair?” I persisted. “Surely that was an unnecessary complication.”  

Holmes shook his head. “Not at all. By making the condition so specific, Clay ensured that Wilson would believe the League to be a genuine, if eccentric, organization. Had the advertisement been open to all, Wilson might have questioned its legitimacy. But the exclusivity of the offer flattered him, appealing to his vanity and ensuring his cooperation.”  

I marveled at the cunning of the criminal mind—and, even more so, at Holmes’s ability to unravel such a tangled web. “And the League itself? Was it entirely fictitious?”  

“Entirely. A mere fabrication, sustained by a few carefully placed references and the payment of a modest salary. The moment Clay and his accomplice had completed their tunnel, the League would have dissolved, leaving Wilson none the wiser until the bank’s gold was long gone.”  

“It is fortunate you intervened when you did,” I observed.  

Holmes smiled faintly. “Indeed. Though I confess, the case presented itself to me as much through Wilson’s peculiar narrative as through the glaring improbability of the Red-Headed League’s existence. No institution, however eccentric, would pay a man simply for the color of his hair. The very absurdity of the proposition betrayed its falsity.”  

I nodded, reflecting on the many cases in which Holmes had demonstrated his uncanny ability to discern truth from deception. “Yet Wilson himself never suspected a thing.”  

“And why should he? The scheme was brilliantly conceived to exploit human nature—greed, curiosity, and the desire for easy gain. Few men would question such a windfall, especially when it required so little effort on their part.”  

“Still,” I mused, “it seems a risky venture. What if Wilson had grown suspicious or decided to investigate the League further?”  

“Ah, but Clay had accounted for that. The League’s supposed dissolution—announced with such theatrical solemnity—was timed to coincide with the completion of the tunnel. By then, Wilson’s brief employment would have served its purpose, and any investigation on his part would have led only to a dead end.”  

Holmes’s explanation left me in silent admiration. The case of the Red-Headed League was a masterpiece of criminal ingenuity—and of detective work.  

“You see, Watson,” Holmes concluded, tapping the ashes from his pipe, “the most effective deceptions are those which appeal to a man’s own inclinations. Had Wilson been less credulous or less enamored of easy money, the scheme might have failed. But Clay understood his mark perfectly—and that, my dear fellow, is the essence of a successful crime.”  

I could not help but agree. And as I recorded the details of the case later that evening, I marveled once more at the intricate dance of intellect between criminal and detective—a dance in which Sherlock Holmes so often led.  

For in the end, it was not merely the advertisement that had betrayed the scheme, but the keen mind that saw through it. And in that, as in so many things, Holmes was without equal.

events.title: The Discovery of the Blue Carbuncle
detailed_summary: Peterson rushes in excitedly, exclaiming about the goose.
He reveals his wife found a brilliant blue gemstone inside the goose's crop.
Holmes examines the stone, recognizing its significance.
Peterson confirms it's a hard stone, likely a diamond.
Holmes identifies it not just as *a* precious stone, but *the* precious stone.
Watson recognizes it as the Countess of Morcar's stolen blue carbuncle.
Holmes confirms, noting its uniqueness and high value (advertised reward of £1000 is far below market price).
Peterson is overwhelmed by the potential reward value.
Holmes adds that sentimental value might make the Countess pay even more.
Watson recalls the stone was lost at the Hotel Cosmopolitan.
Holmes confirms the date (Dec 22nd) and the accused, John Horner, a plumber.
He finds a newspaper account of Horner's arrest and preliminary hearing.
The article details how James Ryder, a hotel attendant, showed Horner to the Countess's room for a repair.

“The goose, Mr. Holmes! The goose, sir!” he gasped, his face flushed with excitement and his hands trembling as he clutched his hat.  

I had never seen our visitor in such a state before. He was a man of steady nerves, a commissionaire by trade, and not one to be easily rattled. Yet here he stood in our sitting room at 221B Baker Street, his breath coming in short, ragged bursts, his eyes wide with urgency.  

Sherlock Holmes, ever the picture of calm, leaned back in his chair and regarded the man with keen interest. “Pray, take a seat, Mr. Baker,” he said in that measured tone of his. “You appear to have had quite the ordeal. A goose, you say?”  

“Yes, sir! The goose!” Mr. Baker repeated, sinking into the chair opposite Holmes. “It’s gone missing, and with it, something of great value!”  

I could not help but raise an eyebrow at this peculiar declaration. A missing goose was hardly the sort of case that typically brought clients to our door, but I had learned long ago that with Holmes, even the most trivial matters often concealed deeper mysteries.  

“Perhaps you would do us the favor of beginning at the beginning,” Holmes suggested, steepling his fingers beneath his chin.  

Mr. Baker nodded vigorously. “Of course, Mr. Holmes. You see, I work as a commissionaire at the Alpha Inn, and last night, a gentleman—a Mr. Henry Baker—left his Christmas goose with me while he stepped out to attend to some business. He was to return for it later, but he never did. This morning, I discovered the goose was gone!”  

Holmes’s eyes gleamed with sudden understanding. “Ah, the infamous Christmas goose. And what, precisely, makes this particular fowl so remarkable?”  

Mr. Baker hesitated, then lowered his voice. “Because, sir, hidden inside that goose was a priceless blue carbuncle!”  

I nearly dropped my teacup. “A blue carbuncle?” I exclaimed. “You mean the Countess of Morcar’s stolen gem?”  

“The very same,” Mr. Baker confirmed. “I didn’t know it at the time, of course. But when I heard the news this morning about the stolen jewel, I put two and two together. The goose must have swallowed it, and now it’s vanished!”  

Holmes sprang to his feet, his languid demeanor replaced by the electric energy that always accompanied a promising case. “Watson, fetch your coat. We have a goose to find.”  

Within minutes, we were out in the crisp winter air, following Mr. Baker through the bustling streets of London. Our first stop was the Alpha Inn, where Holmes questioned the staff with his usual precision. From there, we traced the goose’s path through a series of poultry dealers, each link in the chain bringing us closer to the bird’s mysterious disappearance.  

At last, we found ourselves in the modest home of a breeder named Breckinridge, a surly man who initially denied any knowledge of the missing goose. But Holmes, with his uncanny ability to read men, soon extracted the truth: the goose had been sold to a man matching Henry Baker’s description.  

“Then the trail leads back to Mr. Baker himself,” I mused.  

Holmes shook his head. “Not necessarily, Watson. The gem was inside the goose, but Mr. Baker may have been entirely unaware of it. No, I suspect another party is involved—one who knew the carbuncle’s hiding place and sought to reclaim it.”  

Our investigation took a dramatic turn when we learned that a known thief, James Ryder, had been seen lurking near the Alpha Inn the night before. Ryder, it turned out, had been employed by the Countess of Morcar and had every motive to steal the jewel.  

With Holmes’s usual brilliance, we cornered Ryder in a dingy tavern by the docks. Confronted with the evidence, the man broke down and confessed. He had hidden the carbuncle inside a goose to smuggle it out of the Countess’s estate, only to lose track of the bird in the chaos of London’s markets.  

As we stood outside the tavern, the case resolved, Holmes turned to me with a satisfied smile. “A curious affair, Watson. A stolen jewel, a missing goose, and a lesson in the unexpected places where justice may be found.”  

I could only nod in agreement, marveling once again at my friend’s extraordinary deductive powers. The Adventure of the Blue Carbuncle would go down as yet another triumph in the annals of Sherlock Holmes’s career.

“Hum! So much for the police-court,” said Holmes thoughtfully, tossing aside the paper. “The question for us now to solve is the sequence of events leading from a rifled jewel-case at one end to the crop of a goose in Tottenham Court Road at the other. You see, Watson, our little deductions have suddenly assumed a much more important and less innocent aspect. Here is the stone; the stone came from the goose, and the goose came from Mr. Henry Baker, the gentleman with the bad hat and all the other characteristics with which I have bored you. So now we must set ourselves very seriously to finding this gentleman and ascertaining what part he has played in this little mystery. To do this, we must try the simplest means first, and these lie undoubtedly in an advertisement in all the evening papers. If this fail, I shall have recourse to other methods.”
“What will you say?”
“Give me a pencil and that slip of paper. Now, then: ‘Found at the corner of Goodge Street, a goose and a black felt hat. Mr. Henry Baker can have the same by applying at 6:30 this evening at 221B, Baker Street.’ That is clear and concise.”
“Very. But will he see it?”
“Well, he is sure to keep an eye on the papers, since, to a poor man, the loss was a heavy one. He was clearly so scared by his mischance in breaking the window and by the approach of Peterson that he thought of nothing but flight, but since then he must have bitterly regretted the impulse which caused him to drop his bird. Then, again, the introduction of his name will cause him to see it, for everyone who knows him will direct his attention to it. Here you are, Peterson, run down to the advertising agency and have this put in the evening papers.”
“In which, sir?”
“Oh, in the Globe, Star, Pall Mall, St. James’s Gazette, Evening News, Standard, Echo, and any others that occur to you.”
“Very well, sir. And this stone?”
“Ah, yes, I shall keep the stone. Thank you. And, I say, Peterson, just buy a goose on your way back and leave it here with me, for we must have one to give to this gentleman in place of the one which your family is now devouring.”
When the commissionaire had gone, Holmes took up the stone and held it against the light. “It’s a bonny thing,” said he. “Just see how it glints and sparkles. Of course it is a nucleus and focus of crime. Every good stone is. They are the devil’s pet baits. In the larger and older jewels every facet may stand for a bloody deed. This stone is not yet twenty years old. It was found in the banks of the Amoy River in southern China and is remarkable in having every characteristic of the carbuncle, save that it is blue in shade instead of ruby red. In spite of its youth, it has already a sinister history. There have been two murders, a vitriol-throwing, a suicide, and several robberies brought about for the sake of this forty-grain weight of crystallised charcoal. Who would think that so pretty a toy would be a purveyor to the gallows and the prison? I’ll lock it up in my strong box now and drop a line to the Countess to say that we have it.”
“Do you think that this man Horner is innocent?”
“I cannot tell.”
“Well, then, do you imagine that this other one, Henry Baker, had anything to do with the matter?”
“It is, I think, much more likely that Henry Baker is an absolutely innocent man, who had no idea that the bird which he was carrying was of considerably more value than if it were made of solid gold. That, however, I shall determine by a very simple test if we have an answer to our advertisement.”
“And you can do nothing until then?”
“Nothing.”
“In that case I shall continue my professional round. But I shall come back in the evening at the hour you have mentioned, for I should like to see the solution of so tangled a business.”
“Very glad to see you. I dine at seven. There is a woodcock, I believe. By the way, in view of recent occurrences, perhaps I ought to ask Mrs. Hudson to examine its crop.”

“Hum! So much for the police-court,” said Holmes thoughtfully, tossing aside the paper. “The case, Watson, is one of those singular ones which, though seemingly simple, present a complexity that baffles even the most astute minds. The police, as usual, have taken the most obvious path, but I fear they have missed the subtler clues that lie beneath the surface.”

I looked up from my own reading, intrigued by his tone. “You refer, of course, to the Lamberley forgery case?” I ventured, recalling the headlines of the morning’s news.

“Precisely,” Holmes replied, leaning back in his chair and steepling his fingers. “The police have arrested young Mr. Harold Winstanley on the strength of circumstantial evidence—his handwriting, they claim, matches the forged documents. But there are inconsistencies, Watson, glaring inconsistencies that they have chosen to ignore.”

“Such as?” I asked, eager as ever to follow his reasoning.

Holmes rose and paced the room, his keen eyes alight with the thrill of the chase. “First, the paper upon which the forgeries were written. It is of a peculiar make, imported from Belgium and rarely used in England. Winstanley, a clerk in a modest firm, would hardly have access to such stationery. Second, the ink—a shade of blue so distinctive that it can only be obtained from a single shop in Paris. Does that strike you as the choice of a man who, by all accounts, is neither wealthy nor well-traveled?”

“It does seem unlikely,” I admitted. “But if not Winstanley, then who?”

“Ah, therein lies the puzzle,” Holmes murmured, pausing to gaze out the window at the bustling street below. “The forgeries were executed with a skill that suggests intimate knowledge of the victim’s affairs. Winstanley, though employed by the firm, had no such access. But consider this: the victim’s own brother, Mr. Edgar Lamberley, stands to inherit a considerable fortune should his sibling’s financial ruin be complete. A man of means, well-acquainted with continental stationers, and with every motive to see his brother’s credit destroyed.”

I stared at him in astonishment. “Good heavens, Holmes! Have you communicated this to the police?”

He waved a dismissive hand. “They would not listen. Their case against Winstanley is too neatly wrapped, and they are loath to unravel it. No, Watson, we must act independently. I have already dispatched a telegram to my friend in Paris, confirming the purchase of the ink. Meanwhile, I suggest we pay a visit to Mr. Edgar Lamberley. A man of his standing will doubtless be at his club at this hour.”

Within the hour, we found ourselves in the opulent surroundings of the Diogenes Club, where Edgar Lamberley sat ensconced in a leather armchair, a glass of brandy at his elbow. He was a tall, florid man with a carefully groomed mustache and an air of condescension that grated at once.

“Mr. Holmes,” he said, eyeing us with thinly veiled disdain. “To what do I owe the pleasure? I assure you, I have no interest in the sordid affairs of my brother’s employees.”

“Your brother’s affairs, however, seem to interest you greatly,” Holmes remarked coolly. “Tell me, Mr. Lamberley, when did you last visit Paris?”

The man’s face darkened. “I fail to see what business that is of yours.”

“It is the business of justice,” Holmes replied, his voice sharp as a blade. “The ink used in the forgeries was purchased there, as was the paper. You, sir, are the only one with both the means and the motive to orchestrate this scheme.”

Lamberley’s composure cracked. “This is preposterous! I shall have you thrown out!”

“I think not,” Holmes said, producing a small notebook from his pocket. “I have here the testimony of the Parisian shopkeeper who sold you the ink, as well as the cabdriver who delivered you to the stationer’s. The game is up, Lamberley. Confess, and you may yet spare yourself the gallows.”

For a moment, the man seemed to waver, his face a mask of fury and fear. Then, with a strangled cry, he lunged at Holmes, only to be swiftly subdued by the club’s attendants, summoned by my shouts.

As Lamberley was led away, Holmes turned to me with a satisfied smile. “Another satisfactory conclusion, Watson. The police will have their forgery case solved, though not in the manner they expected.”

“But Winstanley,” I said. “He will be released?”

“At once,” Holmes assured me. “I have already sent word to Inspector Lestrade. Justice, my dear fellow, may be blind, but it must never be stupid.”

And with that, we left the club, stepping out into the crisp London air, where the fog of mystery had once again been dispelled by the brilliance of Sherlock Holmes.

I had been delayed at a case, and it was a little after half-past six when I found myself in Baker Street once more. As I approached the house I saw a tall man in a Scotch bonnet with a coat which was buttoned up to his chin waiting outside in the bright semicircle which was thrown from the fanlight. Just as I arrived the door was opened, and we were shown up together to Holmes’ room.
“Mr. Henry Baker, I believe,” said he, rising from his armchair and greeting his visitor with the easy air of geniality which he could so readily assume. “Pray take this chair by the fire, Mr. Baker. It is a cold night, and I observe that your circulation is more adapted for summer than for winter. Ah, Watson, you have just come at the right time. Is that your hat, Mr. Baker?”
“Yes, sir, that is undoubtedly my hat.”
He was a large man with rounded shoulders, a massive head, and a broad, intelligent face, sloping down to a pointed beard of grizzled brown. A touch of red in nose and cheeks, with a slight tremor of his extended hand, recalled Holmes’ surmise as to his habits. His rusty black frock-coat was buttoned right up in front, with the collar turned up, and his lank wrists protruded from his sleeves without a sign of cuff or shirt. He spoke in a slow staccato fashion, choosing his words with care, and gave the impression generally of a man of learning and letters who had had ill-usage at the hands of fortune.
“We have retained these things for some days,” said Holmes, “because we expected to see an advertisement from you giving your address. I am at a loss to know now why you did not advertise.”
Our visitor gave a rather shamefaced laugh. “Shillings have not been so plentiful with me as they once were,” he remarked. “I had no doubt that the gang of roughs who assaulted me had carried off both my hat and the bird. I did not care to spend more money in a hopeless attempt at recovering them.”
“Very naturally. By the way, about the bird, we were compelled to eat it.”
“To eat it!” Our visitor half rose from his chair in his excitement.
“Yes, it would have been of no use to anyone had we not done so. But I presume that this other goose upon the sideboard, which is about the same weight and perfectly fresh, will answer your purpose equally well?”
“Oh, certainly, certainly,” answered Mr. Baker with a sigh of relief.
“Of course, we still have the feathers, legs, crop, and so on of your own bird, so if you wish—”
The man burst into a hearty laugh. “They might be useful to me as relics of my adventure,” said he, “but beyond that I can hardly see what use the disjecta membra of my late acquaintance are going to be to me. No, sir, I think that, with your permission, I will confine my attentions to the excellent bird which I perceive upon the sideboard.”
Sherlock Holmes glanced sharply across at me with a slight shrug of his shoulders.
“There is your hat, then, and there your bird,” said he. “By the way, would it bore you to tell me where you got the other one from? I am somewhat of a fowl fancier, and I have seldom seen a better grown goose.”
“Certainly, sir,” said Baker, who had risen and tucked his newly gained property under his arm. “There are a few of us who frequent the Alpha Inn, near the Museum—we are to be found in the Museum itself during the day, you understand. This year our good host, Windigate by name, instituted a goose club, by which, on consideration of some few pence every week, we were each to receive a bird at Christmas. My pence were duly paid, and the rest is familiar to you. I am much indebted to you, sir, for a Scotch bonnet is fitted neither to my years nor my gravity.” With a comical pomposity of manner he bowed solemnly to both of us and strode off upon his way.
“So much for Mr. Henry Baker,” said Holmes when he had closed the door behind him. “It is quite certain that he knows nothing whatever about the matter. Are you hungry, Watson?”

I had been delayed at a case, and it was a little after half-past six when I found myself in Baker Street once more. The gas lamps flickered to life as dusk settled over London, casting long shadows across the cobbled streets. My footsteps echoed as I approached the familiar door of 221B, eager to share the details of my day with my friend and colleague, Sherlock Holmes.

Upon entering, I was greeted by the comforting aroma of tobacco and the faint scent of chemicals from one of Holmes’ experiments. The sitting room was in its usual state of organized chaos—papers strewn across the desk, a violin resting carelessly on the sofa, and a stack of newspapers piled haphazardly in the corner. Holmes himself sat by the fire, his long fingers steepled beneath his chin, his sharp eyes fixed on some unseen point in the distance.

"Ah, Watson," he said without turning, "I perceive you’ve had a rather trying day. The mud on your boots suggests you’ve been to the docks, and the ink stain on your cuff tells me you’ve been writing up notes in haste. Am I correct?"

I chuckled, shaking my head. "As always, Holmes, your deductions are uncanny. Indeed, I’ve just come from a rather perplexing case involving a missing shipment at the docks. But how did you know about the ink?"

He gestured vaguely toward my sleeve. "The smudge is fresh, and the way your pen clips your pocket suggests you’ve been in a hurry. But enough about your day—I have something far more intriguing to discuss."

I hung my coat and hat on the rack and took my usual chair by the fire. "Do enlighten me," I said, leaning forward with interest.

Holmes reached for a letter on the table beside him and handed it to me. "This arrived earlier today. Read it aloud, if you would."

I unfolded the crisp paper and began to read:

*"Dear Mr. Holmes,*

*I find myself in a most desperate situation and beg for your assistance. My brother, a man of impeccable character, has vanished without a trace. The police are baffled, and I fear the worst. I shall call upon you tomorrow morning at ten o’clock. Pray, do not refuse me.*  

*Yours in distress,*  
*Miss Evelyn Carrington"*

I looked up at Holmes. "A missing person case? It seems straightforward enough."

Holmes arched an eyebrow. "On the surface, perhaps. But consider the paper—expensive, watermarked, the handwriting elegant yet hurried. Miss Carrington is a woman of means, yet her brother’s disappearance has shaken her composure. And why involve the police if it were a simple matter of a man wandering off? No, Watson, there is more to this than meets the eye."

I nodded, recognizing the familiar spark of excitement in Holmes’ eyes. "Shall I join you for the interview tomorrow?"

"Of course," he replied. "Your presence is always invaluable. But for now, let us dine. Mrs. Hudson has prepared one of her excellent roast beef dinners, and I find myself quite ravenous."

As we sat down to eat, our conversation turned to other matters—the latest developments in criminology, a recent article in *The Times*, and the peculiar habits of our mutual acquaintance, Inspector Lestrade. Yet, despite the pleasant diversion, my mind kept returning to Miss Carrington’s letter. There was an air of mystery about it, a sense of impending drama that I had come to associate with Holmes’ most challenging cases.

After dinner, Holmes retired to his chemistry bench, where he began an experiment involving a peculiar green powder. I, meanwhile, settled into my armchair with a book, though my attention often wandered to the crackling fire and the rhythmic ticking of the clock.

Just as I was beginning to doze, Holmes suddenly straightened, his eyes alight with triumph. "Aha! Just as I suspected. Watson, come here—you must see this!"

I hurried to his side, where he held up a test tube filled with a swirling, iridescent liquid. "What is it?" I asked.

"The final piece of the puzzle in the Henderson forgery case," he said with satisfaction. "This compound reacts only with the specific ink used in the counterfeit documents. Tomorrow, Lestrade will have his proof."

I marveled at his brilliance, as I so often did. Even as he solved one mystery, another loomed on the horizon. And so it was in our shared lodgings at Baker Street—a never-ending parade of puzzles, each more fascinating than the last.

As the clock struck eleven, I bid Holmes goodnight and retired to my room. The events of the day had left me pleasantly weary, yet I found myself lying awake, my thoughts racing with anticipation for the morning’s meeting with Miss Carrington. Whatever mystery she brought to our doorstep, I had no doubt that Sherlock Holmes would unravel it with his usual flair.

And so, with the distant hum of London outside my window, I closed my eyes, eager for the adventures that tomorrow would surely bring.

“By all means.”
It was a bitter night, so we drew on our ulsters and wrapped cravats about our throats. Outside, the stars were shining coldly in a cloudless sky, and the breath of the passers-by blew out into smoke like so many pistol shots. Our footfalls rang out crisply and loudly as we swung through the doctors’ quarter, Wimpole Street, Harley Street, and so through Wigmore Street into Oxford Street. In a quarter of an hour we were in Bloomsbury at the Alpha Inn, which is a small public-house at the corner of one of the streets which runs down into Holborn. Holmes pushed open the door of the private bar and ordered two glasses of beer from the ruddy-faced, white-aproned landlord.
“Your beer should be excellent if it is as good as your geese,” said he.
“My geese!” The man seemed surprised.
“Yes. I was speaking only half an hour ago to Mr. Henry Baker, who was a member of your goose club.”
“Ah! yes, I see. But you see, sir, them’s not our geese.”
“Indeed! Whose, then?”
“Well, I got the two dozen from a salesman in Covent Garden.”
“Indeed? I know some of them. Which was it?”
“Breckinridge is his name.”
“Ah! I don’t know him. Well, here’s your good health landlord, and prosperity to your house. Good-night.”
“Now for Mr. Breckinridge,” he continued, buttoning up his coat as we came out into the frosty air. “Remember, Watson that though we have so homely a thing as a goose at one end of this chain, we have at the other a man who will certainly get seven years’ penal servitude unless we can establish his innocence. It is possible that our inquiry may but confirm his guilt; but, in any case, we have a line of investigation which has been missed by the police, and which a singular chance has placed in our hands. Let us follow it out to the bitter end. Faces to the south, then, and quick march!”

events.title: Confronting Breckinridge the Goose Salesman
detailed_summary: Holmes and Watson navigate through slums to Covent Garden Market.
They locate Breckinridge's stall, where the proprietor is closing up with a boy.
Holmes initiates conversation by remarking on the cold and noting the sold-out geese.
Breckinridge offers to sell him geese the next morning.
Holmes claims he was specifically recommended to Breckinridge by the landlord of the Alpha.
Breckinridge confirms sending geese to the Alpha.
When Holmes asks where Breckinridge got those specific geese, the salesman becomes angry and defensive.
He demands to know Holmes's purpose, complaining about being pestered with questions about the geese.
Holmes feigns indifference but proposes a bet: he wagers a fiver that the goose he ate (Baker's) was country-bred.
Breckinridge snaps that it was town-bred.
Holmes expresses disbelief, provoking Breckinridge to defend his expertise.
Holmes escalates the bet to a sovereign to 'teach him not to be obstinate'.
Breckinridge accepts and calls for his account books.
He shows Holmes his ledger system: one book for suppliers, with separate lists for country and town suppliers.
He points to the town supplier list and asks Holmes to read the third name: 'Mrs. Oakshott, 117, Brixton Road'.
Holmes confirms the corresponding ledger entry for Mrs. Oakshott.
Breckinridge points to the last entry: 'December 22nd. Twenty-four geese at 7s. 6d.'
Underneath, it notes: 'Sold to Mr. Windigate of the Alpha, at 12s.'
Holmes pretends to be chagrined, throws down the sovereign, and walks away.
A short distance away, Holmes laughs quietly, explaining to Watson his strategy of using a bet to extract information from such a character.
He feels they are nearing the end of the quest, needing only to visit Mrs. Oakshott, but notes Breckinridge's agitation suggests others are also searching.

We passed across Holborn, down Endell Street, and so through a zigzag of slums to Covent Garden Market. One of the largest stalls bore the name of Breckinridge upon it, and the proprietor a horsey-looking man, with a sharp face and trim side-whiskers was helping a boy to put up the shutters.
“Good-evening. It’s a cold night,” said Holmes.
The salesman nodded and shot a questioning glance at my companion.
“Sold out of geese, I see,” continued Holmes, pointing at the bare slabs of marble.
“Let you have five hundred to-morrow morning.”
“That’s no good.”
“Well, there are some on the stall with the gas-flare.”
“Ah, but I was recommended to you.”
“Who by?”
“The landlord of the Alpha.”
“Oh, yes; I sent him a couple of dozen.”
“Fine birds they were, too. Now where did you get them from?”
To my surprise the question provoked a burst of anger from the salesman.
“Now, then, mister,” said he, with his head cocked and his arms akimbo, “what are you driving at? Let’s have it straight, now.”
“It is straight enough. I should like to know who sold you the geese which you supplied to the Alpha.”
“Well then, I shan’t tell you. So now!”
“Oh, it is a matter of no importance; but I don’t know why you should be so warm over such a trifle.”
“Warm! You’d be as warm, maybe, if you were as pestered as I am. When I pay good money for a good article there should be an end of the business; but it’s ‘Where are the geese?’ and ‘Who did you sell the geese to?’ and ‘What will you take for the geese?’ One would think they were the only geese in the world, to hear the fuss that is made over them.”
“Well, I have no connection with any other people who have been making inquiries,” said Holmes carelessly. “If you won’t tell us the bet is off, that is all. But I’m always ready to back my opinion on a matter of fowls, and I have a fiver on it that the bird I ate is country bred.”
“Well, then, you’ve lost your fiver, for it’s town bred,” snapped the salesman.
“It’s nothing of the kind.”
“I say it is.”
“I don’t believe it.”
“D’you think you know more about fowls than I, who have handled them ever since I was a nipper? I tell you, all those birds that went to the Alpha were town bred.”
“You’ll never persuade me to believe that.”
“Will you bet, then?”
“It’s merely taking your money, for I know that I am right. But I’ll have a sovereign on with you, just to teach you not to be obstinate.”
The salesman chuckled grimly. “Bring me the books, Bill,” said he.
The small boy brought round a small thin volume and a great greasy-backed one, laying them out together beneath the hanging lamp.
“Now then, Mr. Cocksure,” said the salesman, “I thought that I was out of geese, but before I finish you’ll find that there is still one left in my shop. You see this little book?”
“Well?”
“That’s the list of the folk from whom I buy. D’you see? Well, then, here on this page are the country folk, and the numbers after their names are where their accounts are in the big ledger. Now, then! You see this other page in red ink? Well, that is a list of my town suppliers. Now, look at that third name. Just read it out to me.”
“Mrs. Oakshott, 117, Brixton Road—249,” read Holmes.
“Quite so. Now turn that up in the ledger.”
Holmes turned to the page indicated. “Here you are, ‘Mrs. Oakshott, 117, Brixton Road, egg and poultry supplier.’”
“Now, then, what’s the last entry?”
“‘December 22nd. Twenty-four geese at 7s. 6d.’”
“Quite so. There you are. And underneath?”
“‘Sold to Mr. Windigate of the Alpha, at 12s.’”
“What have you to say now?”
Sherlock Holmes looked deeply chagrined. He drew a sovereign from his pocket and threw it down upon the slab, turning away with the air of a man whose disgust is too deep for words. A few yards off he stopped under a lamp-post and laughed in the hearty, noiseless fashion which was peculiar to him.
“When you see a man with whiskers of that cut and the ‘Pink ’un’ protruding out of his pocket, you can always draw him by a bet,” said he. “I daresay that if I had put £ 100 down in front of him, that man would not have given me such complete information as was drawn from him by the idea that he was doing me on a wager. Well, Watson, we are, I fancy, nearing the end of our quest, and the only point which remains to be determined is whether we should go on to this Mrs. Oakshott to-night, or whether we should reserve it for to-morrow. It is clear from what that surly fellow said that there are others besides ourselves who are anxious about the matter, and I should—”

His remarks were suddenly cut short by a loud hubbub which broke out from the stall which we had just left. Turning round we saw a little rat-faced fellow standing in the centre of the circle of yellow light which was thrown by the swinging lamp, while Breckinridge, the salesman, framed in the door of his stall, was shaking his fists fiercely at the cringing figure.
“I’ve had enough of you and your geese,” he shouted. “I wish you were all at the devil together. If you come pestering me any more with your silly talk I’ll set the dog at you. You bring Mrs. Oakshott here and I’ll answer her, but what have you to do with it? Did I buy the geese off you?”
“No; but one of them was mine all the same,” whined the little man.
“Well, then, ask Mrs. Oakshott for it.”
“She told me to ask you.”
“Well, you can ask the King of Proosia, for all I care. I’ve had enough of it. Get out of this!” He rushed fiercely forward, and the inquirer flitted away into the darkness.
“Ha! this may save us a visit to Brixton Road,” whispered Holmes. “Come with me, and we will see what is to be made of this fellow.” Striding through the scattered knots of people who lounged round the flaring stalls, my companion speedily overtook the little man and touched him upon the shoulder. He sprang round, and I could see in the gas-light that every vestige of colour had been driven from his face.
“Who are you, then? What do you want?” he asked in a quavering voice.
“You will excuse me,” said Holmes blandly, “but I could not help overhearing the questions which you put to the salesman just now. I think that I could be of assistance to you.”
“You? Who are you? How could you know anything of the matter?”
“My name is Sherlock Holmes. It is my business to know what other people don’t know.”
“But you can know nothing of this?”
“Excuse me, I know everything of it. You are endeavouring to trace some geese which were sold by Mrs. Oakshott, of Brixton Road, to a salesman named Breckinridge, by him in turn to Mr. Windigate, of the Alpha, and by him to his club, of which Mr. Henry Baker is a member.”
“Oh, sir, you are the very man whom I have longed to meet,” cried the little fellow with outstretched hands and quivering fingers. “I can hardly explain to you how interested I am in this matter.”
Sherlock Holmes hailed a four-wheeler which was passing. “In that case we had better discuss it in a cosy room rather than in this wind-swept market-place,” said he. “But pray tell me, before we go farther, who it is that I have the pleasure of assisting.”
The man hesitated for an instant. “My name is John Robinson,” he answered with a sidelong glance.
“No, no; the real name,” said Holmes sweetly. “It is always awkward doing business with an alias.”
A flush sprang to the white cheeks of the stranger. “Well then,” said he, “my real name is James Ryder.”
“Precisely so. Head attendant at the Hotel Cosmopolitan. Pray step into the cab, and I shall soon be able to tell you everything which you would wish to know.”
The little man stood glancing from one to the other of us with half-frightened, half-hopeful eyes, as one who is not sure whether he is on the verge of a windfall or of a catastrophe. Then he stepped into the cab, and in half an hour we were back in the sitting-room at Baker Street. Nothing had been said during our drive, but the high, thin breathing of our new companion, and the claspings and unclaspings of his hands, spoke of the nervous tension within him.

events.text_segment:
“Here we are!” said Holmes cheerily as we filed into the room. “The fire looks very seasonable in this weather. You look cold, Mr. Ryder. Pray take the basket-chair. I will just put on my slippers before we settle this little matter of yours. Now, then! You want to know what became of those geese?”
“Yes, sir.”
“Or rather, I fancy, of that goose. It was one bird, I imagine in which you were interested—white, with a black bar across the tail.”
Ryder quivered with emotion. “Oh, sir,” he cried, “can you tell me where it went to?”
“It came here.”
“Here?”
“Yes, and a most remarkable bird it proved. I don’t wonder that you should take an interest in it. It laid an egg after it was dead—the bonniest, brightest little blue egg that ever was seen. I have it here in my museum.”
Our visitor staggered to his feet and clutched the mantelpiece with his right hand. Holmes unlocked his strong-box and held up the blue carbuncle, which shone out like a star, with a cold, brilliant, many-pointed radiance. Ryder stood glaring with a drawn face, uncertain whether to claim or to disown it.
“The game’s up, Ryder,” said Holmes quietly. “Hold up, man, or you’ll be into the fire! Give him an arm back into his chair, Watson. He’s not got blood enough to go in for felony with impunity. Give him a dash of brandy. So! Now he looks a little more human. What a shrimp it is, to be sure!”
For a moment he had staggered and nearly fallen, but the brandy brought a tinge of colour into his cheeks, and he sat staring with frightened eyes at his accuser.
“I have almost every link in my hands, and all the proofs which I could possibly need, so there is little which you need tell me. Still, that little may as well be cleared up to make the case complete. You had heard, Ryder, of this blue stone of the Countess of Morcar’s?”
“It was Catherine Cusack who told me of it,” said he in a crackling voice.
“I see—her ladyship’s waiting-maid. Well, the temptation of sudden wealth so easily acquired was too much for you, as it has been for better men before you; but you were not very scrupulous in the means you used. It seems to me, Ryder, that there is the making of a very pretty villain in you. You knew that this man Horner, the plumber, had been concerned in some such matter before, and that suspicion would rest the more readily upon him. What did you do, then? You made some small job in my lady’s room—you and your confederate Cusack—and you managed that he should be the man sent for. Then, when he had left, you rifled the jewel-case, raised the alarm, and had this unfortunate man arrested. You then—”
Ryder threw himself down suddenly upon the rug and clutched at my companion’s knees. “For God’s sake, have mercy!” he shrieked. “Think of my father! Of my mother! It would break their hearts. I never went wrong before! I never will again. I swear it. I’ll swear it on a Bible. Oh, don’t bring it into court! For Christ’s sake, don’t!”
“Get back into your chair!” said Holmes sternly. “It is very well to cringe and crawl now, but you thought little enough of this poor Horner in the dock for a crime of which he knew nothing.”
“I will fly, Mr. Holmes. I will leave the country, sir. Then the charge against him will break down.”
“Hum! We will talk about that. And now let us hear a true account of the next act. How came the stone into the goose, and how came the goose into the open market? Tell us the truth, for there lies your only hope of safety.”
Ryder passed his tongue over his parched lips. “I will tell you it just as it happened, sir,” said he. “When Horner had been arrested, it seemed to me that it would be best for me to get away with the stone at once, for I did not know at what moment the police might not take it into their heads to search me and my room. There was no place about the hotel where it would be safe. I went out, as if on some commission, and I made for my sister’s house. She had married a man named Oakshott, and lived in Brixton Road, where she fattened fowls for the market. All the way there every man I met seemed to me to be a policeman or a detective; and, for all that it was a cold night, the sweat was pouring down my face before I came to the Brixton Road. My sister asked me what was the matter, and why I was so pale; but I told her that I had been upset by the jewel robbery at the hotel. Then I went into the back yard and smoked a pipe and wondered what it would be best to do.
“I had a friend once called Maudsley, who went to the bad, and has just been serving his time in Pentonville. One day he had met me, and fell into talk about the ways of thieves, and how they could get rid of what they stole. I knew that he would be true to me, for I knew one or two things about him; so I made up my mind to go right on to Kilburn, where he lived, and take him into my confidence. He would show me how to turn the stone into money. But how to get to him in safety? I thought of the agonies I had gone through in coming from the hotel. I might at any moment be seized and searched, and there would be the stone in my waistcoat pocket. I was leaning against the wall at the time and looking at the geese which were waddling about round my feet, and suddenly an idea came into my head which showed me how I could beat the best detective that ever lived.
“My sister had told me some weeks before that I might have the pick of her geese for a Christmas present, and I knew that she was always as good as her word. I would take my goose now, and in it I would carry my stone to Kilburn. There was a little shed in the yard, and behind this I drove one of the birds—a fine big one, white, with a barred tail. I caught it, and prying its bill open, I thrust the stone down its throat as far as my finger could reach. The bird gave a gulp, and I felt the stone pass along its gullet and down into its crop. But the creature flapped and struggled, and out came my sister to know what was the matter. As I turned to speak to her the brute broke loose and fluttered off among the others.
“‘Whatever were you doing with that bird, Jem?’ says she.
“‘Well,’ said I, ‘you said you’d give me one for Christmas, and I was feeling which was the fattest.’
“‘Oh,’ says she, ‘we’ve set yours aside for you—Jem’s bird, we call it. It’s the big white one over yonder. There’s twenty-six of them, which makes one for you, and one for us, and two dozen for the market.’
“‘Thank you, Maggie,’ says I; ‘but if it is all the same to you, I’d rather have that one I was handling just now.’
“‘The other is a good three pound heavier,’ said she, ‘and we fattened it expressly for you.’
“‘Never mind. I’ll have the other, and I’ll take it now,’ said I.
“‘Oh, just as you like,’ said she, a little huffed. ‘Which is it you want, then?’
“‘That white one with the barred tail, right in the middle of the flock.’
“‘Oh, very well. Kill it and take it with you.’
“Well, I did what she said, Mr. Holmes, and I carried the bird all the way to Kilburn. I told my pal what I had done, for he was a man that it was easy to tell a thing like that to. He laughed until he choked, and we got a knife and opened the goose. My heart turned to water, for there was no sign of the stone, and I knew that some terrible mistake had occurred. I left the bird, rushed back to my sister’s, and hurried into the back yard. There was not a bird to be seen there.
“‘Where are they all, Maggie?’ I cried.
“‘Gone to the dealer’s, Jem.’
“‘Which dealer’s?’
“‘Breckinridge, of Covent Garden.’
“‘But was there another with a barred tail?’ I asked, ‘the same as the one I chose?’
“‘Yes, Jem; there were two barred-tailed ones, and I could never tell them apart.’
“Well, then, of course I saw it all, and I ran off as hard as my feet would carry me to this man Breckinridge; but he had sold the lot at once, and not one word would he tell me as to where they had gone. You heard him yourselves to-night. Well, he has always answered me like that. My sister thinks that I am going mad. Sometimes I think that I am myself. And now—and now I am myself a branded thief, without ever having touched the wealth for which I sold my character. God help me! God help me!” He burst into convulsive sobbing, with his face buried in his hands.

“Here we are!” said Holmes cheerily as we filed into the room. The dim glow of the gas lamps cast flickering shadows upon the walls, lending an air of mystery to the already peculiar surroundings. “Pray, take a seat, Mr. Wilson,” Holmes said, gesturing to the chair opposite his own. “And allow me to introduce my friend and colleague, Dr. Watson, whose discretion you may rely upon as fully as my own.”

Mr. Wilson gave a curt nod in my direction before launching into his tale with the air of a man who had long been bursting to unburden himself. “It is a most singular business, Mr. Holmes,” he began, his voice trembling slightly. “I have been the victim of what I can only describe as a most extraordinary and unaccountable series of events.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers beneath his chin, his keen gray eyes fixed upon our visitor with an intensity that seemed to pierce through to the very soul. “I am all attention,” he murmured. “Kindly furnish us with the details, omitting nothing, however trivial it may seem.”

Thus encouraged, Mr. Wilson drew a deep breath and commenced his narrative. “I am, as you may observe, a man of modest means, though not without some small property. For many years, I kept a pawnbroker’s establishment in Coburg Square, which afforded me a comfortable, if unremarkable, living. That is, until three months ago, when I was approached by a gentleman who introduced himself as Mr. Vincent Spaulding.”

At the mention of this name, Holmes’s eyebrows twitched almost imperceptibly, but he made no interruption.

“Mr. Spaulding entered my shop one evening, just as I was preparing to close,” Wilson continued. “He was a bright, eager young fellow, with a shock of red hair and a manner so engaging that I took an instant liking to him. He informed me that he had heard of my business and wished to offer his services as an assistant, as he had some experience in the trade. His terms were remarkably modest—a mere four shillings a week—and I, seeing no reason to refuse, engaged him on the spot.”

“A most economical arrangement,” Holmes remarked dryly. “Pray, continue.”

“For the first few weeks, all went smoothly. Spaulding proved himself an able assistant, diligent and trustworthy. Then, one day, he came to me with a proposition that struck me as highly unusual. He had read in the newspaper of an organization calling itself the Red-Headed League, which offered a peculiar form of employment to men with hair of a particularly vivid shade of red. As my own locks are of a decidedly fiery hue, Spaulding urged me to apply.”

Holmes’s eyes gleamed with sudden interest. “The Red-Headed League,” he repeated softly. “A singular name for a singular institution. And what, precisely, did this league propose?”

“That is the strangest part of it all,” Wilson replied, shaking his head in bewilderment. “The work consisted of nothing more than copying out passages from the Encyclopædia Britannica for four hours each day, for which I was to be paid the princely sum of four pounds a week!”

I could not suppress a gasp of astonishment at this revelation, but Holmes merely nodded, as though such an arrangement were the most natural thing in the world. “And where were you to perform this remarkable labor?” he inquired.

“At the league’s offices, a set of rooms in Pope’s Court, just off Fleet Street. Spaulding himself accompanied me to the interview, where I was examined by one Mr. Duncan Ross, a solemn little man who scrutinized my hair with the utmost care before declaring me eminently suitable for the position. I began my duties the very next day.”

“And how long did this idyllic employment last?” Holmes asked, though I suspected he already knew the answer.

“Exactly eight weeks,” Wilson replied, his voice thick with indignation. “At the end of that time, I arrived at the office as usual, only to find a notice pinned to the door declaring the league dissolved! When I inquired of the landlord, he informed me that he had never heard of Mr. Duncan Ross, nor of the Red-Headed League, and that the rooms had been let to a respectable solicitor some days prior.”

Holmes sprang to his feet with the energy of a man who has at last grasped the thread of a tangled skein. “Capital, Mr. Wilson, capital! Your case presents features of the most remarkable interest. But tell me—this assistant of yours, Mr. Spaulding—how long had he been in your employ before suggesting you apply to the league?”

Wilson frowned in thought. “Let me see… it would have been about a month.”

“And during that time, did he ever express any particular interest in your premises? Your vault, perhaps, or the habits of your neighbors?”

“Why, now that you mention it,” Wilson said slowly, “he did seem uncommonly curious about the cellar. And he was forever popping out on errands, though he always returned promptly enough.”

Holmes clapped his hands together with a sound like a pistol shot. “Then I think we may consider the mystery well on its way to being solved! But there is no time to lose. Watson, fetch your revolver. Mr. Wilson, I must ask you to accompany us to Coburg Square at once.”

“But what is the meaning of all this?” our bewildered client demanded as we hastened into a hansom cab. “What possible connection can there be between my red hair and the disappearance of the league?”

Holmes’s eyes sparkled with mischief. “My dear sir, your hair, while undoubtedly striking, is merely the bait in a far more elaborate trap. But fear not—by the time this night is through, I fancy we shall have the answers you seek.”

As the cab rattled through the fog-shrouded streets of London, I could not help but marvel at the singular genius of my friend, whose mind seemed to dance always two steps ahead of the rest of the world. Little did I suspect, as we alighted before the darkened shop in Coburg Square, that the night’s adventures were only just beginning—or that they would lead us into one of the most daring and audacious criminal schemes it had ever been my privilege to witness.

But that, as they say, is another story.

There was a long silence, broken only by his heavy breathing and by the measured tapping of Sherlock Holmes’ finger-tips upon the edge of the table. Then my friend rose and threw open the door.
“Get out!” said he.
“What, sir! Oh, Heaven bless you!”
“No more words. Get out!”
And no more words were needed. There was a rush, a clatter upon the stairs, the bang of a door, and the crisp rattle of running footfalls from the street.
“After all, Watson,” said Holmes, reaching up his hand for his clay pipe, “I am not retained by the police to supply their deficiencies. If Horner were in danger it would be another thing; but this fellow will not appear against him, and the case must collapse. I suppose that I am commuting a felony, but it is just possible that I am saving a soul. This fellow will not go wrong again; he is too terribly frightened. Send him to gaol now, and you make him a gaol-bird for life. Besides, it is the season of forgiveness. Chance has put in our way a most singular and whimsical problem, and its solution is its own reward. If you will have the goodness to touch the bell, Doctor, we will begin another investigation, in which, also a bird will be the chief feature.”
