On glancing over my notes of the seventy odd cases in which I have during the last eight years studied the methods of my friend Sherlock Holmes, I find many tragic, some comic, a large number merely strange, but none commonplace; for, working as he did rather for the love of his art than for the acquirement of wealth, he refused to associate himself with any investigation which did not tend towards the unusual, and even the fantastic. Of all these varied cases, however, I cannot recall any which presented more singular features than that which was associated with the well-known Surrey family of the Roylotts of Stoke Moran. The events in question occurred in the early days of my association with Holmes, when we were sharing rooms as bachelors in Baker Street. It is possible that I might have placed them upon record before, but a promise of secrecy was made at the time, from which I have only been freed during the last month by the untimely death of the lady to whom the pledge was given. It is perhaps as well that the facts should now come to light, for I have reasons to know that there are widespread rumours as to the death of Dr. Grimesby Roylott which tend to make the matter even more terrible than the truth.
It was early in April in the year ’83 that I woke one morning to find Sherlock Holmes standing, fully dressed, by the side of my bed. He was a late riser, as a rule, and as the clock on the mantelpiece showed me that it was only a quarter-past seven, I blinked up at him in some surprise, and perhaps just a little resentment, for I was myself regular in my habits.
“Very sorry to knock you up, Watson,” said he, “but it’s the common lot this morning. Mrs. Hudson has been knocked up, she retorted upon me, and I on you.”
“What is it, then—a fire?”
“No; a client. It seems that a young lady has arrived in a considerable state of excitement, who insists upon seeing me. She is waiting now in the sitting-room. Now, when young ladies wander about the metropolis at this hour of the morning, and knock sleepy people up out of their beds, I presume that it is something very pressing which they have to communicate. Should it prove to be an interesting case, you would, I am sure, wish to follow it from the outset. I thought, at any rate, that I should call you and give you the chance.”
“My dear fellow, I would not miss it for anything.”
I had no keener pleasure than in following Holmes in his professional investigations, and in admiring the rapid deductions, as swift as intuitions, and yet always founded on a logical basis with which he unravelled the problems which were submitted to him. I rapidly threw on my clothes and was ready in a few minutes to accompany my friend down to the sitting-room. A lady dressed in black and heavily veiled, who had been sitting in the window, rose as we entered.
“Good-morning, madam,” said Holmes cheerily. “My name is Sherlock Holmes. This is my intimate friend and associate, Dr. Watson, before whom you can speak as freely as before myself. Ha! I am glad to see that Mrs. Hudson has had the good sense to light the fire. Pray draw up to it, and I shall order you a cup of hot coffee, for I observe that you are shivering.”
“It is not cold which makes me shiver,” said the woman in a low voice, changing her seat as requested.
“What, then?”
“It is fear, Mr. Holmes. It is terror.” She raised her veil as she spoke, and we could see that she was indeed in a pitiable state of agitation, her face all drawn and grey, with restless frightened eyes, like those of some hunted animal. Her features and figure were those of a woman of thirty, but her hair was shot with premature grey, and her expression was weary and haggard. Sherlock Holmes ran her over with one of his quick, all-comprehensive glances.
“You must not fear,” said he soothingly, bending forward and patting her forearm. “We shall soon set matters right, I have no doubt. You have come in by train this morning, I see.”
“You know me, then?”
“No, but I observe the second half of a return ticket in the palm of your left glove. You must have started early, and yet you had a good drive in a dog-cart, along heavy roads, before you reached the station.”
The lady gave a violent start and stared in bewilderment at my companion.
“There is no mystery, my dear madam,” said he, smiling. “The left arm of your jacket is spattered with mud in no less than seven places. The marks are perfectly fresh.

**The Singular Methods of Sherlock Holmes**  

On glancing over my notes of the seventy-odd cases in which I have during the last eight years studied the methods of my friend Sherlock Holmes, I find many tragic, some comic, a large number merely strange, but none commonplace; for, working as he did rather for the love of his art than for the acquirement of wealth, he refused to associate himself with any investigation which did not tend towards the unusual, and even the fantastic.  

Of all these varied cases, however, I have seldom encountered one which so perfectly illustrated his peculiar faculties as that which I now lay before the public. It was not the most dramatic, nor the most perilous, but in its singular details and the remarkable deductions drawn from them, it stands as a prime example of Holmes’s extraordinary mind.  

### **The Case of the Vanishing Violinist**  

It began on a dreary November evening, the kind that drives even the most resolute indoors. Holmes and I sat before the fire in our Baker Street lodgings, he immersed in a chemical experiment—some new test for bloodstains—while I perused the evening paper. The wind howled outside, rattling the windows as though demanding entry.  

Suddenly, there came a sharp rap at the door. Mrs. Hudson ushered in a young woman, her face pale with distress, her gloved hands trembling.  

“Mr. Holmes,” she gasped, “I beg your assistance. My brother has disappeared under the most inexplicable circumstances!”  

Holmes, ever alert to the promise of an intriguing problem, set aside his test tubes and motioned for her to sit. “Pray, compose yourself, Miss…?”  

“Harrison. Clara Harroway—that is, Clara Harroway was my name before my marriage. My brother is Julian Harroway, a violinist of some repute.”  

“Ah,” said Holmes, his keen eyes alight. “I have heard of him. A rising star in the musical world, I believe.”  

“Yes, until three nights ago, when he vanished without a trace.”  

She went on to explain that Julian had been preparing for an important concert, practicing late into the night in his rooms near Covent Garden. His landlady had heard him playing as usual, but the next morning, his door was locked from the inside, his violin gone, and no sign of Julian himself. The window was fastened, the room undisturbed—save for a single sheet of music left upon the stand, a piece he had never played before.  

Holmes leaned forward, his fingers steepled. “Most singular. And this music—was it in his hand?”  

“No, it was not his writing. It was… strange. The notes were correct, but the style was unlike anything he composed or performed.”  

“Fascinating,” murmured Holmes. “Watson, we must examine this room at once.”  

### **The Locked Room Mystery**  

The scene was precisely as Miss Harroway had described. The door had been bolted from within, the window secured. No footprints marred the dusty sill, no signs of struggle disturbed the neatly arranged furniture. The violin case lay open and empty, its velvet lining undisturbed.  

Holmes moved about the room like a bloodhound, his sharp eyes missing nothing. He examined the sheet of music, sniffed the air, and even pressed his ear to the floorboards. At last, he paused before the fireplace, a slow smile spreading across his face.  

“Watson, observe the grate.”  

I peered into the fireplace. “There are ashes, but no signs of a recent fire.”  

“Precisely. And yet, the air carries the faintest scent of resin—violin rosin, unless I am mistaken.” He knelt and plucked something from the ashes—a single blackened hair.  

“A man’s, by the thickness,” he mused. “But not Harroway’s—his is lighter. Our mystery deepens.”  

Suddenly, his gaze fixed upon the ceiling. “Ah! The answer lies above!”  

Before I could question him, Holmes had dragged a chair beneath a small trapdoor in the ceiling—an access point for repairs, nearly invisible unless one knew to look for it. With a heave, he pushed it open, revealing a cramped attic space.  

There, bound and gagged, lay Julian Harroway, his face bruised but alive.  

### **The Solution**  

Once freed, the violinist explained that he had been attacked by a rival musician, a man envious of his rising fame. The assailant had entered through the attic, overpowered him, and staged the disappearance to cast suspicion upon Julian’s sanity—leaving the strange music as a taunt.  

“But how did you deduce the attic, Holmes?” I asked as we returned to Baker Street.  

“Elementary, my dear Watson. The locked door and window ruled out ordinary entry. The scent of rosin suggested recent handling of a violin, yet Harroway’s was missing. The hair in the ashes—too coarse to be his—indicated a struggle. The only remaining point of entry was above.”  

Thus concluded another of Holmes’s remarkable cases, proving once more that no mystery, however baffling, could long resist the power of his deductive genius.  

And so, as I record these adventures, I am reminded that the world is full of wonders, if only one knows how to look for them—as Sherlock Holmes, the most perfect reasoning and observing machine the world has ever seen, so masterfully demonstrated time and again.

events.title: Helen Stoner's Narrative: Family History and Julia's Engagement
detailed_summary: The client, startled by Holmes's deductions but confirming their accuracy, reveals the extreme stress she is under.
She explains her journey and mentions Mrs. Farintosh as the source of Holmes's address, appealing for his help in her dire situation.
She clarifies her current inability to pay but promises remuneration after her upcoming marriage.
Holmes reassures her that his profession is its own reward, only asking for expenses to be covered eventually.
He requests she share all details, despite her fears seeming vague and dismissed by others as nervousness.
The client introduces herself as Helen Stoner, living with her stepfather, Dr. Grimesby Roylott, the last of the Roylotts of Stoke Moran.
She recounts the family's decline from wealth, her stepfather's medical career in Calcutta, his violent past (killing his butler), and subsequent imprisonment.
Helen explains her mother, a widow with substantial wealth, married Dr. Roylott in India.
The inheritance stipulated annual sums for Helen and her twin sister Julia upon their marriages.
After their mother's death in a railway accident, Dr. Roylott abandoned his London practice and moved them to the ancestral home.
A drastic negative change occurred in Roylott; he became reclusive, prone to violent outbursts, and alienated the neighbours, becoming feared in the village.
He associated only with wandering gipsies and kept exotic Indian animals (a cheetah and a baboon) that roamed freely.
Helen describes the isolated and unpleasant life she and Julia endured, doing all housework as servants wouldn't stay.
She reveals Julia died two years prior, shortly after becoming engaged to a marine major met during a visit to their aunt, Miss Honoria Westphail.
Dr. Roylott had not initially objected to the engagement, but Julia died suddenly a fortnight before the planned wedding.

This keen observation was made by Sherlock Holmes as we stood by the roadside, examining the peculiar pattern of mud splashes on the hedge. It was a crisp autumn morning, and the damp earth bore clear evidence of recent wheel tracks. My friend’s remarkable ability to deduce the most minute details never ceased to astonish me.

“You see, Watson,” Holmes continued, pointing to the irregular spray of mud, “the distribution is quite distinctive. A dog-cart, being a light, two-wheeled vehicle, throws up mud in a particular fashion—especially when the passenger sits on the left side, as the right wheel is unobstructed and thus flings dirt more freely. The angle and spread of these marks confirm it.”

I nodded, though I confess I could scarcely follow the intricacies of his reasoning. “But what does this tell us, Holmes?” I asked. “Surely there are many dog-carts in the countryside.”

“Ah, but not all dog-carts are driven at such a pace,” he replied, his sharp eyes scanning the road. “Observe the depth of the ruts—this was no leisurely trot. The driver was in a hurry, and the horse was pushed to a gallop. Furthermore, the mud is fresh; this cart passed within the last hour.”

Holmes knelt and plucked a small object from the mud—a shred of fabric, dark green in color. He held it up to the light, examining it with the intensity of a scientist peering through a microscope. “Wool, Watson. A fragment torn from a coat, most likely. Our hurried driver wore a garment of some quality, and the tear suggests a struggle or a hasty exit.”

I felt a thrill of excitement. “Then we are on the trail of someone in distress?”

“Or someone causing distress,” Holmes murmured. “Come, the tracks lead this way.”

We followed the muddy trail along the lane, which wound through a patch of woodland before opening onto a broader road. Here, the tracks merged with others, but Holmes’s keen eyes picked out the distinctive marks of the dog-cart turning sharply to the right. 

“They’ve taken the road to Milford,” he said. “A quiet village, scarcely more than a hamlet. Few visitors pass that way unless they have business there.”

As we walked, Holmes shared his thoughts. “The speed of the cart, the torn fabric—these suggest urgency. The driver may have been fleeing or pursuing. The presence of a passenger on the left side is also notable. Most drivers sit alone, unless accompanied. This implies a second person, possibly unwilling.”

“A kidnapping?” I ventured.

“It is a possibility,” Holmes admitted. “Though we must not leap to conclusions without further evidence.”

At that moment, we heard the distant sound of hoofbeats. A farmer on a sturdy cob rounded the bend ahead, his face ruddy from the morning chill. Holmes hailed him.

“Good morning! Have you seen a dog-cart pass this way recently? Driven at some speed?”

The farmer tugged his hat in greeting. “Aye, sir, not half an hour ago. Nearly ran me off the road, they did. A dark-haired fellow driving, wild-eyed like the devil was after him. Had another man with him, slumped over like he was ill or worse.”

Holmes’s eyes gleamed. “Did you notice anything else? The color of the cart, perhaps?”

“Black, I reckon, with yellow wheels. Horse was a bay, lathered with sweat. Headed toward Milford, like I said.”

“Thank you, you’ve been most helpful,” Holmes said, pressing a coin into the man’s hand.

As the farmer rode off, Holmes turned to me. “The plot thickens, Watson. A man slumped over—unconscious or worse. And the driver in a state of agitation. We must make haste.”

We quickened our pace, and before long, the rooftops of Milford came into view. It was a sleepy village, its few cottages clustered around a small green. The dog-cart’s tracks led us to the inn, where the bay horse stood tethered, still panting from its exertions. The cart itself was empty.

Holmes approached the innkeeper, a stout man wiping his hands on an apron. “We’re looking for two men who arrived recently—one driving a dog-cart, the other possibly unwell.”

The innkeeper’s expression darkened. “Aye, they’re here. The one fellow carried the other inside—said he’d taken ill on the road. But I’ve my doubts. The sick one’s pale as death, and the other’s been acting queer, locking the door and such.”

“Which room?” Holmes demanded.

“Upstairs, first on the left. But I’d be careful, sir. That one’s got a look about him.”

Holmes needed no further urging. We bounded up the stairs, and without knocking, he threw open the door. Inside, a swarthy man spun around, his hand darting to his coat. On the bed lay another man, his wrists bound, a gag in his mouth. His eyes widened at the sight of us.

“Stand where you are!” Holmes commanded, his voice like steel. “Watson, see to the prisoner.”

I rushed to the bed and removed the gag, while Holmes advanced on the captor. The man snarled and drew a knife, but Holmes moved with lightning speed, disarming him with a sharp twist of the wrist. The knife clattered to the floor, and the man howled in pain.

“You’ll hang for this,” Holmes said coldly. “Kidnapping is a capital offense.”

The prisoner on the bed gasped out his story between breaths. “He—he ambushed me on the road. Wanted my money, my papers. Would have killed me if not for you.”

Holmes smiled faintly. “A dog-cart throws up mud in a particular way—especially when driven at speed. The rest was a matter of deduction.”

As we left the inn, I marveled once more at my friend’s genius. “Holmes, your powers of observation are beyond compare.”

He waved a dismissive hand. “Elementary, my dear Watson. The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any chance ever observes. Now, let us return to Baker Street. I believe Mrs. Hudson has promised us one of her excellent steak-and-kidney pies for supper.”

Sherlock Holmes had been leaning back in his chair with his eyes closed and his head sunk in a cushion, but he half opened his lids now and glanced across at his visitor.
“Pray be precise as to details,” said he.
“It is easy for me to be so, for every event of that dreadful time is seared into my memory. The manor-house is, as I have already said, very old, and only one wing is now inhabited. The bedrooms in this wing are on the ground floor, the sitting-rooms being in the central block of the buildings. Of these bedrooms the first is Dr. Roylott’s, the second my sister’s, and the third my own. There is no communication between them, but they all open out into the same corridor. Do I make myself plain?”
“Perfectly so.”
“The windows of the three rooms open out upon the lawn. That fatal night Dr. Roylott had gone to his room early, though we knew that he had not retired to rest, for my sister was troubled by the smell of the strong Indian cigars which it was his custom to smoke. She left her room, therefore, and came into mine, where she sat for some time, chatting about her approaching wedding. At eleven o’clock she rose to leave me, but she paused at the door and looked back.
“‘Tell me, Helen,’ said she, ‘have you ever heard anyone whistle in the dead of the night?’
“‘Never,’ said I.
“‘I suppose that you could not possibly whistle, yourself, in your sleep?’
“‘Certainly not. But why?’
“‘Because during the last few nights I have always, about three in the morning, heard a low, clear whistle. I am a light sleeper, and it has awakened me. I cannot tell where it came from—perhaps from the next room, perhaps from the lawn. I thought that I would just ask you whether you had heard it.’
“‘No, I have not. It must be those wretched gipsies in the plantation.’
“‘Very likely. And yet if it were on the lawn, I wonder that you did not hear it also.’
“‘Ah, but I sleep more heavily than you.’
“‘Well, it is of no great consequence, at any rate.’ She smiled back at me, closed my door, and a few moments later I heard her key turn in the lock.”
“Indeed,” said Holmes. “Was it your custom always to lock yourselves in at night?”
“Always.”
“And why?”
“I think that I mentioned to you that the Doctor kept a cheetah and a baboon. We had no feeling of security unless our doors were locked.”
“Quite so. Pray proceed with your statement.”
“I could not sleep that night. A vague feeling of impending misfortune impressed me. My sister and I, you will recollect, were twins, and you know how subtle are the links which bind two souls which are so closely allied. It was a wild night. The wind was howling outside, and the rain was beating and splashing against the windows. Suddenly, amid all the hubbub of the gale, there burst forth the wild scream of a terrified woman. I knew that it was my sister’s voice. I sprang from my bed, wrapped a shawl round me, and rushed into the corridor. As I opened my door I seemed to hear a low whistle, such as my sister described, and a few moments later a clanging sound, as if a mass of metal had fallen. As I ran down the passage, my sister’s door was unlocked, and revolved slowly upon its hinges. I stared at it horror-stricken, not knowing what was about to issue from it. By the light of the corridor-lamp I saw my sister appear at the opening, her face blanched with terror, her hands groping for help, her whole figure swaying to and fro like that of a drunkard. I ran to her and threw my arms round her, but at that moment her knees seemed to give way and she fell to the ground. She writhed as one who is in terrible pain, and her limbs were dreadfully convulsed. At first I thought that she had not recognised me, but as I bent over her she suddenly shrieked out in a voice which I shall never forget, ‘Oh, my God! Helen! It was the band! The speckled band!’ There was something else which she would fain have said, and she stabbed with her finger into the air in the direction of the Doctor’s room, but a fresh convulsion seized her and choked her words. I rushed out, calling loudly for my stepfather, and I met him hastening from his room in his dressing-gown. When he reached my sister’s side she was unconscious, and though he poured brandy down her throat and sent for medical aid from the village, all efforts were in vain, for she slowly sank and died without having recovered her consciousness. Such was the dreadful end of my beloved sister.”
“One moment,” said Holmes, “are you sure about this whistle and metallic sound? Could you swear to it?”
“That was what the county coroner asked me at the inquiry. It is my strong impression that I heard it, and yet, among the crash of the gale and the creaking of an old house, I may possibly have been deceived.”
“Was your sister dressed?”
“No, she was in her night-dress. In her right hand was found the charred stump of a match, and in her left a match-box.”
“Showing that she had struck a light and looked about her when the alarm took place. That is important. And what conclusions did the coroner come to?”
“He investigated the case with great care, for Dr. Roylott’s conduct had long been notorious in the county, but he was unable to find any satisfactory cause of death. My evidence showed that the door had been fastened upon the inner side, and the windows were blocked by old-fashioned shutters with broad iron bars, which were secured every night. The walls were carefully sounded, and were shown to be quite solid all round, and the flooring was also thoroughly examined, with the same result. The chimney is wide, but is barred up by four large staples. It is certain, therefore, that my sister was quite alone when she met her end. Besides, there were no marks of any violence upon her.”
“How about poison?”
“The doctors examined her for it, but without success.”
“What do you think that this unfortunate lady died of, then?”
“It is my belief that she died of pure fear and nervous shock, though what it was that frightened her I cannot imagine.”
“Were there gipsies in the plantation at the time?”
“Yes, there are nearly always some there.”
“Ah, and what did you gather from this allusion to a band—a speckled band?”
“Sometimes I have thought that it was merely the wild talk of delirium, sometimes that it may have referred to some band of people, perhaps to these very gipsies in the plantation. I do not know whether the spotted handkerchiefs which so many of them wear over their heads might have suggested the strange adjective which she used.”
Holmes shook his head like a man who is far from being satisfied.

"I perceive that you have come from the south-west of London, that you are a man of some means, though not extravagant, and that you have recently been engaged in a matter of some delicacy—possibly involving a lady. But forgive me; I see by your expression that I have startled you. Let us proceed to the business at hand."

The visitor, a stout, red-faced gentleman of middle age, gaped at Holmes for a moment before sinking into the chair opposite. "Good heavens, Mr. Holmes! How on earth could you know all that?"

Holmes waved a thin hand dismissively. "Elementary, my dear sir. The mud on your boots is of a peculiar reddish hue, found only in certain districts south-west of the city. Your watch-chain is of good quality but not ostentatious, indicating moderate wealth. As for the lady, the faint but unmistakable scent of lily of the valley—a perfume favored by women of refinement—clings to your sleeve, and the slight abrasion on your left ring finger suggests the recent removal of a wedding band. Now, what brings you to Baker Street?"

The man, whose name was Mr. James Fairbank, leaned forward eagerly. "You are quite correct in every particular, Mr. Holmes. My name is Fairbank, and I am indeed recently widowed. But it is not my own affairs that bring me here—it is those of my niece, Miss Clara Ashworth. A most distressing matter has arisen, and I fear it may require your unique talents."

Holmes steepled his fingers beneath his chin. "Pray continue."

Fairbank mopped his brow with a handkerchief before speaking. "Clara is the only daughter of my late brother, and since his death, she has resided with me at my home in Richmond. She is a quiet, sensible girl of twenty, not given to flights of fancy. Yet three nights ago, she came to me in a state of great agitation, insisting that she was being followed."

"Followed?" Holmes's eyebrows rose slightly. "By whom?"

"That is just the trouble—she cannot say. She claims to have seen the same sinister figure lurking near the house on several occasions, a tall man wrapped in a dark cloak who vanishes whenever she attempts to confront him. Last night, she awoke to find a single black rose placed upon her pillow—a rose that none in the household could account for."

"A black rose," murmured Holmes. "An unusual choice. Did your niece recognize its significance?"

Fairbank shook his head. "She has no notion of its meaning, nor do I. But the effect upon her has been profound. She refuses to leave her room, convinced that some terrible fate awaits her. I have consulted the local police, but they dismiss it as a girlish fancy. Yet I know Clara—she is not one to imagine such things."

Holmes rose abruptly and reached for his coat. "This is a matter that warrants immediate attention. I shall accompany you to Richmond at once, Mr. Fairbank. Watson, you will join us, of course."

Within the hour, we found ourselves in the comfortable drawing-room of Fairbank's residence, a handsome villa overlooking the Thames. Miss Ashworth, a pale, dark-eyed young woman with an air of quiet dignity, received us with visible relief.

"Mr. Holmes, I cannot tell you what a comfort it is to have you here," she said, her hands clasped tightly in her lap. "I know how foolish I must sound, but I swear to you, I am not imagining these things."

Holmes seated himself opposite her, his keen eyes studying her face. "I do not for a moment doubt you, Miss Ashworth. Now, tell me—have you any enemies? Any reason someone might wish to frighten you?"

She shook her head. "None that I know of. My life has been very quiet since my father's death. I rarely go out, except to visit the lending library or to walk in the garden."

"And the man you saw—can you describe him in more detail?"

She shuddered slightly. "He was very tall, and though his face was always in shadow, I had the impression of something... unnatural about him. His movements were oddly silent, as though he glided rather than walked. And once, when the moonlight struck him, I thought I saw—" She broke off, pressing a hand to her mouth.

"What did you see?" Holmes asked gently.

"A face that was not human," she whispered. "A face like a skull."

Fairbank made a noise of protest. "Now, Clara, you see how this sounds! Mr. Holmes will think you've been reading too many Gothic novels."

But Holmes held up a hand. "Let us not dismiss anything prematurely. Miss Ashworth, this black rose—had you ever seen its like before?"

"No, never. It was perfectly fresh, as though just cut, yet there are no black roses in our garden—nor in any garden I know of."

Holmes rose and paced the room. "I should like to see the rose, if it has been preserved."

"It has," said Fairbank. "I had the presence of mind to keep it." He produced a small box from his pocket and handed it to Holmes.

Holmes examined the flower minutely, even going so far as to sniff it delicately. "Most interesting. This is no ordinary rose—it has been dyed, and with a substance I do not immediately recognize. Watson, what do you make of the scent?"

I took the rose and inhaled cautiously. "There is something beneath the floral aroma—a faint, acrid tang. Almost like... arsenic?"

Holmes's eyes gleamed. "Precisely. Not enough to harm, but enough to leave a trace. Someone is sending a very deliberate message, Miss Ashworth. The question is—why?"

At that moment, a housemaid entered, her face white with fright. "Sir—there's a man at the garden gate! A tall man in black, just as Miss Clara described!"

Holmes sprang into action. "Watson, with me! Mr. Fairbank, bar the doors and allow no one to enter. Miss Ashworth, remain here." With that, he dashed into the garden, I close behind.

The moon cast eerie shadows across the lawn as we raced toward the gate. Sure enough, a cloaked figure stood there, motionless as a statue. At our approach, he turned—and I caught a glimpse of a face so ghastly, so inhuman, that my blood ran cold. Then, with a swirl of his cloak, he was gone, vanishing into the night like smoke.

Holmes gave chase, but the figure had disappeared without a trace. Returning to the gate, he bent to examine the ground. "Ah! Our specter leaves tangible evidence after all." He held up a small, crumpled slip of paper. "A pawnbroker's ticket, Watson—and unless I am very much mistaken, the key to this mystery."

Holmes nodded gravely. "Miss Ashworth, the man who has been haunting you is none other than your uncle—your father's twin brother, long believed dead. Her stepfather offered no objection to this marriage either.
Two days prior, alleged repairs began on her bedroom wall, forcing her to move into Julia's old room and sleep in the same bed.

Holmes commends her action but presses if she has told him everything, sensing she is protecting her stepfather.
He reveals five livid bruises on her wrist, marks from a four-fingered grip.

After a thoughtful silence, Holmes declares the matter extremely deep and urgent.

Helen confirms Roylott plans to be in town all day and she can manage the housekeeper.
Holmes confirms Watson's willingness to accompany him.
Helen plans to run errands and return to Stoke Moran by midday.
Holmes declines her offer of breakfast, and Helen departs, feeling relieved after sharing her burden.

“These are very deep waters,” said he; “pray go on with your narrative.”
“Two years have passed since then, and my life has been until lately lonelier than ever. A month ago, however, a dear friend, whom I have known for many years, has done me the honour to ask my hand in marriage. His name is Armitage—Percy Armitage—the second son of Mr. Armitage, of Crane Water, near Reading. My stepfather has offered no opposition to the match, and we are to be married in the course of the spring. Two days ago some repairs were started in the west wing of the building, and my bedroom wall has been pierced, so that I have had to move into the chamber in which my sister died, and to sleep in the very bed in which she slept. Imagine, then, my thrill of terror when last night, as I lay awake, thinking over her terrible fate, I suddenly heard in the silence of the night the low whistle which had been the herald of her own death. I sprang up and lit the lamp, but nothing was to be seen in the room. I was too shaken to go to bed again, however, so I dressed, and as soon as it was daylight I slipped down, got a dog-cart at the Crown Inn, which is opposite, and drove to Leatherhead, from whence I have come on this morning with the one object of seeing you and asking your advice.”
“You have done wisely,” said my friend. “But have you told me all?”
“Yes, all.”
“Miss Roylott, you have not. You are screening your stepfather.”
“Why, what do you mean?”
For answer Holmes pushed back the frill of black lace which fringed the hand that lay upon our visitor’s knee. Five little livid spots, the marks of four fingers and a thumb, were printed upon the white wrist.
“You have been cruelly used,” said Holmes.
The lady coloured deeply and covered over her injured wrist. “He is a hard man,” she said, “and perhaps he hardly knows his own strength.”
There was a long silence, during which Holmes leaned his chin upon his hands and stared into the crackling fire.
“This is a very deep business,” he said at last. “There are a thousand details which I should desire to know before I decide upon our course of action. Yet we have not a moment to lose. If we were to come to Stoke Moran to-day, would it be possible for us to see over these rooms without the knowledge of your stepfather?”
“As it happens, he spoke of coming into town to-day upon some most important business. It is probable that he will be away all day, and that there would be nothing to disturb you. We have a housekeeper now, but she is old and foolish, and I could easily get her out of the way.”
“Excellent. You are not averse to this trip, Watson?”
“By no means.”
“Then we shall both come. What are you going to do yourself?”
“I have one or two things which I would wish to do now that I am in town. But I shall return by the twelve o’clock train, so as to be there in time for your coming.”
“And you may expect us early in the afternoon. I have myself some small business matters to attend to. Will you not wait and breakfast?”
“No, I must go. My heart is lightened already since I have confided my trouble to you. I shall look forward to seeing you again this afternoon.” She dropped her thick black veil over her face and glided from the room.

Holmes acknowledges its nature but questions how Julia could have met her end alone if the room was secured.
He points out the inconsistencies: the nocturnal whistles and Julia's dying words.
Holmes speculates a possible connection between the whistles, the gipsies, Roylott's motive to prevent the marriage, the 'band' reference, and the metallic clang (perhaps a falling shutter bar).
Both acknowledge significant objections to this theory, necessitating the visit to Stoke Moran.
Suddenly, the door bursts open, revealing a huge, imposing man identified as Dr. Grimesby Roylott.
Roylott aggressively demands to know which one is Holmes and confirms his stepdaughter visited.
Holmes attempts polite deflection, but Roylott furiously repeats his demand.
Roylott threatens Holmes, calling him a meddler and busybody.
To demonstrate his strength and menace, Roylott seizes the fireplace poker and bends it into a curve.
He warns Holmes to stay out of his affairs and grip, then throws the poker down and storms out.
Holmes remarks on Roylott's 'amiable' nature and, picking up the poker, effortlessly straightens it again.
He finds Roylott's confounding him with official detectives amusing and notes the incident adds zest to the case, though he worries for Helen's safety.
Holmes suggests breakfast before he heads out for research.

“And what do you think of it all, Watson?” asked Sherlock Holmes, leaning back in his chair.
“It seems to me to be a most dark and sinister business.”
“Dark enough and sinister enough.”
“Yet if the lady is correct in saying that the flooring and walls are sound, and that the door, window, and chimney are impassable, then her sister must have been undoubtedly alone when she met her mysterious end.”
“What becomes, then, of these nocturnal whistles, and what of the very peculiar words of the dying woman?”
“I cannot think.”
“When you combine the ideas of whistles at night, the presence of a band of gipsies who are on intimate terms with this old doctor, the fact that we have every reason to believe that the doctor has an interest in preventing his stepdaughter’s marriage, the dying allusion to a band, and, finally, the fact that Miss Helen Stoner heard a metallic clang, which might have been caused by one of those metal bars that secured the shutters falling back into its place, I think that there is good ground to think that the mystery may be cleared along those lines.”
“But what, then, did the gipsies do?”
“I cannot imagine.”
“I see many objections to any such theory.”
“And so do I. It is precisely for that reason that we are going to Stoke Moran this day. I want to see whether the objections are fatal, or if they may be explained away. But what in the name of the devil!”
The ejaculation had been drawn from my companion by the fact that our door had been suddenly dashed open, and that a huge man had framed himself in the aperture. His costume was a peculiar mixture of the professional and of the agricultural, having a black top-hat, a long frock-coat, and a pair of high gaiters, with a hunting-crop swinging in his hand. So tall was he that his hat actually brushed the cross bar of the doorway, and his breadth seemed to span it across from side to side. A large face, seared with a thousand wrinkles, burned yellow with the sun, and marked with every evil passion, was turned from one to the other of us, while his deep-set, bile-shot eyes, and his high, thin, fleshless nose, gave him somewhat the resemblance to a fierce old bird of prey.
“Which of you is Holmes?” asked this apparition.
“My name, sir; but you have the advantage of me,” said my companion quietly.
“I am Dr. Grimesby Roylott, of Stoke Moran.”
“Indeed, Doctor,” said Holmes blandly. “Pray take a seat.”
“I will do nothing of the kind. My stepdaughter has been here. I have traced her. What has she been saying to you?”
“It is a little cold for the time of the year,” said Holmes.
“What has she been saying to you?” screamed the old man furiously.
“But I have heard that the crocuses promise well,” continued my companion imperturbably.
“Ha! You put me off, do you?” said our new visitor, taking a step forward and shaking his hunting-crop. “I know you, you scoundrel! I have heard of you before. You are Holmes, the meddler.”
My friend smiled.
“Holmes, the busybody!”
His smile broadened.
“Holmes, the Scotland Yard Jack-in-office!”
Holmes chuckled heartily. “Your conversation is most entertaining,” said he. “When you go out close the door, for there is a decided draught.”
“I will go when I have had my say. Don’t you dare to meddle with my affairs. I know that Miss Stoner has been here. I traced her! I am a dangerous man to fall foul of! See here.” He stepped swiftly forward, seized the poker, and bent it into a curve with his huge brown hands.
“See that you keep yourself out of my grip,” he snarled, and hurling the twisted poker into the fireplace he strode out of the room.
“He seems a very amiable person,” said Holmes, laughing. “I am not quite so bulky, but if he had remained I might have shown him that my grip was not much more feeble than his own.” As he spoke he picked up the steel poker and, with a sudden effort, straightened it out again.
“Fancy his having the insolence to confound me with the official detective force! This incident gives zest to our investigation, however, and I only trust that our little friend will not suffer from her imprudence in allowing this brute to trace her. And now, Watson, we shall order breakfast, and afterwards I shall walk down to Doctors’ Commons, where I hope to get some data which may help us in this matter.”

I hesitated for a moment, puffing thoughtfully on my pipe before answering. The case before us was indeed a perplexing one—a matter of stolen jewels, a missing heiress, and a series of cryptic notes that seemed to lead nowhere. Holmes had spent the better part of the evening examining the evidence with his usual meticulous care, while I had done my best to follow his deductions. Yet, as often happened, I found myself several steps behind his brilliant mind.  

“I confess, Holmes,” I said at last, “I cannot make head nor tail of it. The clues seem contradictory. The jewels were taken from Lady Carrington’s safe, yet there is no sign of forced entry. The heiress, Miss Violet, vanishes without a trace, leaving behind only a single glove in her carriage. And these notes—” I gestured to the three slips of paper on the table, each bearing a single, enigmatic word: *raven*, *midnight*, *silence*. “They appear to be nonsense.”  

Holmes’s eyes gleamed with that familiar spark of excitement. “Ah, but therein lies the beauty of it, Watson! When the facts seem impossible, we must look beyond the obvious. Consider: Lady Carrington’s safe was opened without force—who but someone with intimate knowledge of the household could achieve such a feat? Miss Violet’s disappearance coincides precisely with the theft, yet no ransom demand has been made. And as for these words—” He tapped the notes with a long, slender finger. “They are not nonsense, but a code. A code meant for someone.”  

I frowned. “A code? But to what end?”  

“That, my dear Watson, is the question we must answer.” Holmes rose abruptly and strode to the window, peering out into the fog-shrouded streets of London. “Tell me, what do you know of the Carrington family?”  

I searched my memory. “Lord Carrington died some years ago, leaving his fortune to his daughter, Miss Violet. Lady Carrington, his widow, has managed the estate since. There were rumors of financial difficulties, but nothing confirmed.”  

“Precisely,” Holmes murmured. “And yet, the Carringtons were once among the wealthiest families in England. What could have caused such a reversal of fortune?”  

I shook my head. “Gambling debts, perhaps? Or poor investments?”  

Holmes turned back to me, his expression grave. “Or something far more deliberate. Watson, I believe we are dealing not with a simple theft, but with a carefully orchestrated plot—one that has been years in the making.”  

Before I could press him further, there came a sharp knock at the door. Mrs. Hudson entered, bearing a telegram. Holmes snatched it up, his eyes scanning the message rapidly. A slow smile spread across his face.  

“The game is afoot, Watson! Our missing heiress has been sighted—at a small inn near Dover. And our mysterious correspondent has sent another note.” He handed me the telegram. It contained but a single word: *revenge*.  

I felt a chill run down my spine. “Holmes, this grows darker by the minute. What does it mean?”  

“It means, Watson, that we have no time to lose. Pack your revolver—we leave for Dover at once.”  

Within the hour, we were aboard a train, speeding through the night. Holmes sat in silence, his keen mind no doubt piecing together the fragments of the puzzle. I, meanwhile, could not shake the sense of foreboding that had settled over me. The word *revenge* echoed in my thoughts, hinting at motives far more personal than mere greed.  

As the train rattled onward, Holmes finally spoke. “Watson, there is something you should know. Lord Carrington did not die of natural causes. He was murdered.”  

I stared at him in shock. “Murdered? But it was reported as a heart attack!”  

“A convenient fiction,” Holmes replied grimly. “I have long suspected foul play, but the evidence was buried—quite literally. Now, it seems, the past has returned to claim its due.”  

The pieces began to fall into place. “Then Miss Violet’s disappearance—the stolen jewels—it’s all connected?”  

“Indubitably. And unless we reach her in time, I fear the final act of this tragedy will be written in blood.”  

The train whistle shrieked into the night, a mournful sound that seemed to herald the darkness ahead. Somewhere in Dover, a young woman’s life hung in the balance—and with it, the truth of a crime long hidden.  

Holmes’s eyes burned with determination. “The stakes could not be higher, Watson. Let us hope we are not too late.”  

And with that, we plunged onward into the heart of the mystery.

events.title: Discovery of Motive and Journey to Stoke Moran
detailed_summary: Holmes returns around 1 PM with notes from the deceased Mrs. Stoner's will.
He has calculated the current value of the estate, finding the income significantly reduced.
Each daughter's marriage would cost Roylott £250 annually from his diminished income of £750.
This confirms Roylott has a strong financial motive to prevent his stepdaughters' marriages.
Recognizing the urgency, especially now that Roylott knows they are involved, Holmes tells Watson to prepare for their trip to Waterloo, advising him to bring his revolver.
They catch a train to Leatherhead and hire a trap for the drive through Surrey.
Watson contrasts the beautiful spring day with their sinister mission.
Holmes points out Stoke Moran manor in the distance.
The driver suggests a shortcut across the fields via a stile, pointing out Helen Stoner walking there.
Holmes decides to take the footpath, telling the driver they are architects to prevent gossip.
They meet Helen, who joyfully reports Roylott has gone to town.
Holmes informs her of their encounter with Roylott; Helen turns pale, realizing he followed her.
Holmes reassures her they will be more cunning and advises her to lock herself away from Roylott that night, promising protection if he becomes violent.
He urges haste to examine the rooms.

It was nearly one o’clock when Sherlock Holmes returned from his excursion. He held in his hand a sheet of blue paper, scrawled over with notes and figures.
“I have seen the will of the deceased wife,” said he. “To determine its exact meaning I have been obliged to work out the present prices of the investments with which it is concerned. The total income, which at the time of the wife’s death was little short of £ 1,100, is now, through the fall in agricultural prices, not more than £ 750. Each daughter can claim an income of £ 250, in case of marriage. It is evident, therefore, that if both girls had married, this beauty would have had a mere pittance, while even one of them would cripple him to a very serious extent. My morning’s work has not been wasted, since it has proved that he has the very strongest motives for standing in the way of anything of the sort. And now, Watson, this is too serious for dawdling, especially as the old man is aware that we are interesting ourselves in his affairs; so if you are ready, we shall call a cab and drive to Waterloo. I should be very much obliged if you would slip your revolver into your pocket. An Eley’s No. 2 is an excellent argument with gentlemen who can twist steel pokers into knots. That and a tooth-brush are, I think, all that we need.”
At Waterloo we were fortunate in catching a train for Leatherhead, where we hired a trap at the station inn and drove for four or five miles through the lovely Surrey lanes. It was a perfect day, with a bright sun and a few fleecy clouds in the heavens. The trees and wayside hedges were just throwing out their first green shoots, and the air was full of the pleasant smell of the moist earth. To me at least there was a strange contrast between the sweet promise of the spring and this sinister quest upon which we were engaged. My companion sat in the front of the trap, his arms folded, his hat pulled down over his eyes, and his chin sunk upon his breast, buried in the deepest thought. Suddenly, however, he started, tapped me on the shoulder, and pointed over the meadows.
“Look there!” said he.
A heavily timbered park stretched up in a gentle slope, thickening into a grove at the highest point. From amid the branches there jutted out the grey gables and high roof-tree of a very old mansion.
“Stoke Moran?” said he.
“Yes, sir, that be the house of Dr. Grimesby Roylott,” remarked the driver.
“There is some building going on there,” said Holmes; “that is where we are going.”
“There’s the village,” said the driver, pointing to a cluster of roofs some distance to the left; “but if you want to get to the house, you’ll find it shorter to get over this stile, and so by the footpath over the fields. There it is, where the lady is walking.”
“And the lady, I fancy, is Miss Stoner,” observed Holmes, shading his eyes. “Yes, I think we had better do as you suggest.”
We got off, paid our fare, and the trap rattled back on its way to Leatherhead.
“I thought it as well,” said Holmes as we climbed the stile, “that this fellow should think we had come here as architects, or on some definite business. It may stop his gossip. Good-afternoon, Miss Stoner. You see that we have been as good as our word.”
Our client of the morning had hurried forward to meet us with a face which spoke her joy. “I have been waiting so eagerly for you,” she cried, shaking hands with us warmly. “All has turned out splendidly. Dr. Roylott has gone to town, and it is unlikely that he will be back before evening.”
“We have had the pleasure of making the Doctor’s acquaintance,” said Holmes, and in a few words he sketched out what had occurred. Miss Stoner turned white to the lips as she listened.
“Good heavens!” she cried, “he has followed me, then.”
“So it appears.”
“He is so cunning that I never know when I am safe from him. What will he say when he returns?”
“He must guard himself, for he may find that there is someone more cunning than himself upon his track. You must lock yourself up from him to-night. If he is violent, we shall take you away to your aunt’s at Harrow. Now, we must make the best use of our time, so kindly take us at once to the rooms which we are to examine.”

It was nearly one o’clock when Sherlock Holmes returned from his excursion. His face was flushed with excitement, and his eyes gleamed with that peculiar light which I had learned to associate with the successful unraveling of a perplexing case. He flung himself into his armchair and stretched out his long legs toward the fire, rubbing his hands together with evident satisfaction.

“Well, Watson,” he said, “I trust you have not been entirely idle in my absence?”

I laid aside the medical journal I had been perusing and shook my head. “I have been occupied with my own studies, Holmes, but nothing so thrilling as whatever has occupied you this morning. Pray, do not keep me in suspense any longer. What have you discovered?”

Holmes chuckled and reached for his pipe, which lay upon the mantelpiece. “It is a singular case, Watson, one that promises to engage even your practical mind. You recall the matter of the Baskerville hound, do you not?”

“Indeed,” I replied, “though I fail to see what connection that has with your present investigation.”

“None whatsoever,” said Holmes, striking a match and lighting his pipe. “But it serves to illustrate the point that the most outlandish appearances often conceal the simplest truths. This morning’s affair is no exception.”

He leaned back, blowing a series of smoke rings toward the ceiling. “I have been to Camberwell,” he continued, “where a most respectable banker, Mr. Alexander Hamilton, reported the theft of a diamond necklace worth some twenty thousand pounds. The local police were baffled, for there was no sign of forced entry, and the safe in which the necklace was kept showed no evidence of tampering.”

“A most curious business,” I remarked. “And yet, I gather you have already formed some theory?”

“Not a theory, Watson—a certainty. The facts, once properly arranged, point unmistakably to the culprit. But I shall not spoil the pleasure of your own deductions. Tell me, what would you make of a case where a valuable necklace vanishes from a locked safe, with no sign of intrusion?”

I considered for a moment. “The most obvious conclusion is that the safe was not properly locked, or that the thief had access to the combination.”

Holmes shook his head. “The safe was indeed locked, and the combination known only to Mr. Hamilton and his wife.”

“Then perhaps the wife—”

“No, Watson,” Holmes interrupted with a smile. “Mrs. Hamilton was visiting her sister in Bath at the time of the theft. Her alibi is unimpeachable.”

“A servant, then?”

“The servants have been with the family for years, and none have any history of dishonesty. Besides, the safe is in Mr. Hamilton’s private study, to which only he and his wife have regular access.”

I threw up my hands in frustration. “Then I confess myself at a loss, Holmes. The necklace could not have simply vanished into thin air!”

“And yet it did,” said Holmes, his eyes twinkling. “Or rather, it appeared to. The key, my dear Watson, lies in the fact that Mr. Hamilton is an avid collector of tropical fish.”

I stared at him. “Tropical fish? What on earth have they to do with the theft?”

“Everything,” replied Holmes. “You see, the safe in question stands directly beside a large aquarium in Mr. Hamilton’s study. The thief—a man of considerable ingenuity—used the aquarium as his means of entry.”

“But how?”

“By introducing a small, specially trained octopus into the tank. The creature, guided by the thief’s signals from outside the window, slipped through a gap in the aquarium’s lid, crossed the short distance to the safe, and manipulated the dial with its tentacles. Once the safe was open, it retrieved the necklace and returned the same way.”

I was astounded. “An octopus! Holmes, surely you are joking.”

“Not in the least. The thief, a former marine biologist turned criminal, had perfected the method over several months. He was apprehended this morning attempting to sell the necklace to a discreet jeweler in Soho. The octopus, I am happy to report, has been returned unharmed to its natural habitat.”

I could only shake my head in amazement. “It is incredible, Holmes. And yet, knowing you, I suppose it is all perfectly logical.”

“Elementary, my dear Watson,” said he, with a satisfied smile. “The most bizarre solutions are often the correct ones. But come, let us put aside this case for the moment. I perceive by the clock that it is time for lunch, and Mrs. Hudson has outdone herself with a particularly fine roast beef.”

And with that, my remarkable friend turned his attention to more mundane matters, leaving me to marvel once again at the extraordinary workings of his mind.

events.title: Examination of Stoke Moran Manor
detailed_summary: Watson describes the dilapidated manor house.
Holmes examines the exterior of the three relevant bedroom windows, confirming their occupants and Helen's current use of the middle room.
He notes the lack of actual need for repairs on the end wall, suggesting it was an excuse to move Helen.
He confirms the corridor windows are too small to enter through.
Holmes tests the shutters from outside while Helen bars them from within, finding them impenetrable.
Acknowledging difficulties with his theory, they move inside via a side door.
They proceed directly to the middle bedroom (Julia's former room, now Helen's).
Holmes silently observes every detail of the sparsely furnished room.
He inquires about a thick, relatively new bell-rope hanging by the bed.
Helen confirms it was installed about two years ago but never used by Julia or herself.
Holmes examines the floorboards and paneling with his lens.
He tugs the bell-rope and discovers it's a dummy, not connected to any wire, but fastened to a hook above a small ventilator near the ceiling.
Helen expresses surprise, having never noticed this.
Holmes remarks on the absurdity of a ventilator opening into another room instead of outside, learning it's also a recent addition, concurrent with the bell-rope.
They move to Dr. Roylott's larger, plainly furnished room.
Holmes examines the contents: camp-bed, books, chairs, table, and a large iron safe.
He asks about the safe's contents (papers) and finds a saucer of milk on top.
Helen confirms they have no cat, only the cheetah and baboon.
Holmes examines the seat of a wooden chair near the safe intently.
His eye catches a small dog lash curled into a loop hanging on the bed.

The building was of grey, lichen-blotched stone, with a high central portion and two curving wings, like the claws of a crab, thrown out on each side. In one of these wings the windows were broken and blocked with wooden boards, while the roof was partly caved in, a picture of ruin. The central portion was in little better repair, but the right-hand block was comparatively modern, and the blinds in the windows, with the blue smoke curling up from the chimneys, showed that this was where the family resided. Some scaffolding had been erected against the end wall, and the stone-work had been broken into, but there were no signs of any workmen at the moment of our visit. Holmes walked slowly up and down the ill-trimmed lawn and examined with deep attention the outsides of the windows.
“This, I take it, belongs to the room in which you used to sleep, the centre one to your sister’s, and the one next to the main building to Dr. Roylott’s chamber?”
“Exactly so. But I am now sleeping in the middle one.”
“Pending the alterations, as I understand. By the way, there does not seem to be any very pressing need for repairs at that end wall.”
“There were none. I believe that it was an excuse to move me from my room.”
“Ah! that is suggestive. Now, on the other side of this narrow wing runs the corridor from which these three rooms open. There are windows in it, of course?”
“Yes, but very small ones. Too narrow for anyone to pass through.”
“As you both locked your doors at night, your rooms were unapproachable from that side. Now, would you have the kindness to go into your room and bar your shutters?”
Miss Stoner did so, and Holmes, after a careful examination through the open window, endeavoured in every way to force the shutter open, but without success. There was no slit through which a knife could be passed to raise the bar. Then with his lens he tested the hinges, but they were of solid iron, built firmly into the massive masonry. “Hum!” said he, scratching his chin in some perplexity, “my theory certainly presents some difficulties. No one could pass these shutters if they were bolted. Well, we shall see if the inside throws any light upon the matter.”
A small side door led into the whitewashed corridor from which the three bedrooms opened. Holmes refused to examine the third chamber, so we passed at once to the second, that in which Miss Stoner was now sleeping, and in which her sister had met with her fate. It was a homely little room, with a low ceiling and a gaping fireplace, after the fashion of old country-houses. A brown chest of drawers stood in one corner, a narrow white-counterpaned bed in another, and a dressing-table on the left-hand side of the window. These articles, with two small wicker-work chairs, made up all the furniture in the room save for a square of Wilton carpet in the centre. The boards round and the panelling of the walls were of brown, worm-eaten oak, so old and discoloured that it may have dated from the original building of the house. Holmes drew one of the chairs into a corner and sat silent, while his eyes travelled round and round and up and down, taking in every detail of the apartment.
“Where does that bell communicate with?” he asked at last pointing to a thick bell-rope which hung down beside the bed, the tassel actually lying upon the pillow.
“It goes to the housekeeper’s room.”
“It looks newer than the other things?”
“Yes, it was only put there a couple of years ago.”
“Your sister asked for it, I suppose?”
“No, I never heard of her using it. We used always to get what we wanted for ourselves.”
“Indeed, it seemed unnecessary to put so nice a bell-pull there. You will excuse me for a few minutes while I satisfy myself as to this floor.” He threw himself down upon his face with his lens in his hand and crawled swiftly backward and forward, examining minutely the cracks between the boards. Then he did the same with the wood-work with which the chamber was panelled. Finally he walked over to the bed and spent some time in staring at it and in running his eye up and down the wall. Finally he took the bell-rope in his hand and gave it a brisk tug.
“Why, it’s a dummy,” said he.
“Won’t it ring?”
“No, it is not even attached to a wire. This is very interesting. You can see now that it is fastened to a hook just above where the little opening for the ventilator is.”
“How very absurd! I never noticed that before.”
“Very strange!” muttered Holmes, pulling at the rope. “There are one or two very singular points about this room. For example, what a fool a builder must be to open a ventilator into another room, when, with the same trouble, he might have communicated with the outside air!”
“That is also quite modern,” said the lady.
“Done about the same time as the bell-rope?” remarked Holmes.
“Yes, there were several little changes carried out about that time.”
“They seem to have been of a most interesting character—dummy bell-ropes, and ventilators which do not ventilate. With your permission, Miss Stoner, we shall now carry our researches into the inner apartment.”
Dr. Grimesby Roylott’s chamber was larger than that of his step-daughter, but was as plainly furnished. A camp-bed, a small wooden shelf full of books, mostly of a technical character, an armchair beside the bed, a plain wooden chair against the wall, a round table, and a large iron safe were the principal things which met the eye. Holmes walked slowly round and examined each and all of them with the keenest interest.
“What’s in here?” he asked, tapping the safe.
“My stepfather’s business papers.”
“Oh! you have seen inside, then?”
“Only once, some years ago. I remember that it was full of papers.”
“There isn’t a cat in it, for example?”
“No. What a strange idea!”
“Well, look at this!” He took up a small saucer of milk which stood on the top of it.
“No; we don’t keep a cat. But there is a cheetah and a baboon.”
“Ah, yes, of course! Well, a cheetah is just a big cat, and yet a saucer of milk does not go very far in satisfying its wants, I daresay. There is one point which I should wish to determine.” He squatted down in front of the wooden chair and examined the seat of it with the greatest attention.
“Thank you. That is quite settled,” said he, rising and putting his lens in his pocket. “Hullo! Here is something interesting!”
The object which had caught his eye was a small dog lash hung on one corner of the bed. The lash, however, was curled upon itself and tied so as to make a loop of whipcord.
“What do you make of that, Watson?”
“It’s a common enough lash. But I don’t know why it should be tied.”
“That is not quite so common, is it? Ah, me! it’s a wicked world, and when a clever man turns his brains to crime it is the worst of all. I think that I have seen enough now, Miss Stoner, and with your permission we shall walk out upon the lawn.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The building was of grey, lichen-blotched stone, with a high central portion and two curving wings, like the claws of a crab, thrown out on each side. It stood upon a bleak and windswept moor, its sombre silhouette cutting sharply against the leaden sky. The air was thick with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves, and the distant cry of a moorland bird only served to heighten the sense of desolation.

As I approached, the heavy oak door groaned on its hinges, as if reluctant to admit any visitor. The interior was scarcely more inviting—a vast, shadowy hall lined with portraits of stern-faced ancestors, their eyes seeming to follow my every move. The flickering light of a single candle cast grotesque shadows upon the walls, and the silence was so profound that I could hear the steady ticking of a long-case clock in some distant corridor.

A figure emerged from the gloom—a tall, gaunt man with piercing eyes and a manner that was at once courteous and guarded. "You are expected, Dr. Watson," he said in a voice that was little more than a whisper. "Mr. Holmes awaits you in the library."

I followed him down a narrow passageway, my footsteps muffled by the thick Persian carpet. The library, when we reached it, was a cavernous room lined from floor to ceiling with leather-bound volumes. A fire crackled in the hearth, its glow illuminating the angular features of Sherlock Holmes, who sat hunched over a desk strewn with papers and odd-looking instruments.

"Ah, Watson," he said without looking up. "I trust your journey was uneventful?"

"Quite," I replied, taking the seat he indicated. "But I confess I am at a loss as to why you summoned me to such a remote place."

Holmes finally raised his eyes, and I saw in them the familiar gleam of excitement that heralded the beginning of a new case. "Because, my dear fellow, we stand upon the threshold of one of the most singular and perplexing mysteries it has ever been my privilege to encounter."

He pushed a sheet of paper toward me. "Read that," he commanded.

The handwriting was spidery and uneven, as though the author had been in great agitation when he penned it. The message was brief and cryptic: *"The hour is at hand. The curse of the Baskervilles is upon us. Beware the moor. Beware the hound."*

I looked up, puzzled. "What on earth does this mean?"

Holmes leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers. "That, Watson, is what we are here to discover. The note was delivered to Sir Henry Baskerville, the last of his line, who inherited this estate upon the sudden and tragic death of his uncle, Sir Charles. The circumstances of Sir Charles's demise were... unusual, to say the least."

"Unusual in what way?" I asked, my curiosity thoroughly aroused.

"He was found dead on the moor, his face contorted in an expression of sheer terror. There were no marks of violence upon his body, save for the footprints of a gigantic hound leading away from the scene."

I felt a chill run down my spine. "You cannot seriously believe in some spectral beast?"

Holmes smiled enigmatically. "I believe only in what the evidence tells me, Watson. And the evidence thus far suggests that someone—or something—wishes Sir Henry to share his uncle's fate."

At that moment, the door burst open, and a young man strode into the room. He was tall and well-built, with the bronzed complexion of one who has spent much time outdoors. His eyes, however, were shadowed with anxiety.

"Mr. Holmes!" he exclaimed. "I've just returned from the moor, and I swear I saw it—the hound! It was enormous, its eyes glowing like coals in the darkness!"

Holmes rose swiftly. "Calm yourself, Sir Henry. Tell me exactly what you saw."

The young man sank into a chair, his hands trembling. "I was walking near the old stone circle when I heard a sound—a low, guttural growl. I turned, and there it was, not twenty yards away. It stared at me for a moment, then vanished into the mist."

Holmes's eyes gleamed with renewed intensity. "This is most opportune. Watson, we must act at once. The game, as they say, is afoot."

And so it was that we found ourselves, that very night, lying in wait upon the moor. The fog had rolled in, reducing visibility to mere feet, and the only sounds were the occasional rustle of the wind through the heather and the distant, mournful cry of a nightjar.

Hours passed, and just as I was beginning to doubt the wisdom of our vigil, I heard it—a deep, resonant baying that seemed to come from all directions at once. Holmes gripped my arm. "Steady, Watson," he murmured. "Do not move until I give the word."

Then, out of the mist, it came—a monstrous black hound, its eyes indeed glowing with an unearthly light. It moved with a terrifying grace, its massive paws making no sound upon the damp earth.

Holmes raised his pistol and fired. The creature let out a howl of pain and rage, then turned and fled into the night.

We gave chase, but the fog and the uneven terrain soon forced us to abandon the pursuit. As we made our way back to the house, Holmes was unusually silent.

"Well?" I asked at last. "What do you make of it?"

He shook his head. "There is more here than meets the eye, Watson. That was no supernatural beast, but a living creature—trained and set upon Sir Henry for reasons yet unknown. Tomorrow, we must redouble our efforts to uncover the truth."

And so began one of the strangest and most thrilling adventures of my long association with Sherlock Holmes—an adventure that would test his deductive powers to their limits and plunge us both into mortal danger. But that, as they say, is another story.

detailed_summary: Holmes stresses the absolute importance of Helen following his instructions precisely, as her life depends on it.
He informs Helen and Watson that he and Watson must spend the night in her current bedroom.
He points out the village inn (The Crown) from which her window is visible.
He instructs Helen to feign a headache upon Roylott's return, wait until he retires, then open her window shutters and place her lamp as a signal.
She must then quietly move to her original room for the night.
Holmes assures her they will handle the rest and investigate the noise.
Helen senses Holmes has solved the case and pleads to know Julia's cause of death.
Holmes prefers clearer proof before speaking but dismisses her theory of death by fright, suggesting a more tangible cause.
They leave quickly to avoid Roylott's return.
Holmes and Watson secure rooms at The Crown Inn with a view of the manor.
They observe Dr. Roylott's return at dusk, noting his menacing behaviour towards the boy driving the trap.
As darkness falls, Holmes expresses concerns about the danger Watson faces that night, but Watson insists on coming.

Holmes explains his deductions: the cigar smell implied a connection between rooms, leading him to expect the ventilator; its installation coinciding with the dummy bell-rope and Julia's death is suspicious.
He points out the bed is clamped to the floor, always positioned relative to the ventilator and the rope (intended as a bridge, not a bell-pull).
Watson begins to understand the horrific implications.
Holmes remarks on the danger of a criminal doctor with nerve and knowledge, suggesting they await the night's horrors after a calming pipe.

events.text_segment:
I had never seen my friend’s face so grim or his brow so dark as it was when we turned from the scene of this investigation. We had walked several times up and down the lawn, neither Miss Stoner nor myself liking to break in upon his thoughts before he roused himself from his reverie.
“It is very essential, Miss Stoner,” said he, “that you should absolutely follow my advice in every respect.”
“I shall most certainly do so.”
“The matter is too serious for any hesitation. Your life may depend upon your compliance.”
“I assure you that I am in your hands.”
“In the first place, both my friend and I must spend the night in your room.”
Both Miss Stoner and I gazed at him in astonishment.
“Yes, it must be so. Let me explain. I believe that that is the village inn over there?”
“Yes, that is the Crown.”
“Very good. Your windows would be visible from there?”
“Certainly.”
“You must confine yourself to your room, on pretence of a headache, when your stepfather comes back. Then when you hear him retire for the night, you must open the shutters of your window, undo the hasp, put your lamp there as a signal to us, and then withdraw quietly with everything which you are likely to want into the room which you used to occupy. I have no doubt that, in spite of the repairs, you could manage there for one night.”
“Oh, yes, easily.”
“The rest you will leave in our hands.”
“But what will you do?”
“We shall spend the night in your room, and we shall investigate the cause of this noise which has disturbed you.”
“I believe, Mr. Holmes, that you have already made up your mind,” said Miss Stoner, laying her hand upon my companion’s sleeve.
“Perhaps I have.”
“Then, for pity’s sake, tell me what was the cause of my sister’s death.”
“I should prefer to have clearer proofs before I speak.”
“You can at least tell me whether my own thought is correct, and if she died from some sudden fright.”

The weight of the case pressed heavily upon him, and I could see the lines of deep thought etched upon his features. As we walked in silence through the dimly lit streets of London, the gas lamps flickering uncertainly in the evening mist, I dared not interrupt his brooding. Holmes was a man who, when confronted with a particularly vexing problem, would retreat into the recesses of his own mind, shutting out the world until the solution presented itself.  

At last, as we turned onto Baker Street, he spoke, his voice low and measured.  

“Watson,” he said, “there are times when the darkness of men’s hearts eclipses even the blackest deeds we have encountered. This case is one such instance.”  

I nodded, though I did not yet fully grasp the depths of his meaning. The facts, as I understood them, were these: a respected banker, Mr. Alistair Wainwright, had been found dead in his study, a single gunshot wound to the temple. The weapon lay beside him, and all signs pointed to suicide. Yet Holmes had been called in by the man’s distraught widow, who insisted that her husband would never take his own life.  

Upon our arrival at the Wainwright residence, Holmes had examined the scene with his usual meticulous care. He had noted the position of the body, the angle of the wound, the absence of powder burns, and the peculiar arrangement of papers upon the desk. He had questioned the servants, the butler, and the widow herself, his keen eyes missing nothing.  

Now, as we ascended the steps to our lodgings, I ventured to ask, “What troubles you so, Holmes? The evidence seems clear enough.”  

He turned to me, his eyes burning with an intensity that sent a chill down my spine. “Clear? Watson, it is too clear. That is precisely what troubles me. The scene has been arranged—and arranged by someone who wished us to believe in the obvious.”  

Mrs. Hudson greeted us at the door, her kind face lined with concern as she took in Holmes’s expression. “You’ve had a trying evening, Mr. Holmes,” she observed. “Shall I bring up some tea?”  

“Thank you, Mrs. Hudson,” Holmes replied absently, already striding toward the sitting room. I followed, knowing that his mind was already racing ahead, piecing together the fragments of the puzzle.  

Once seated before the fire, Holmes lit his pipe and exhaled a long, contemplative plume of smoke. “Consider the facts, Watson,” he began. “A man is found dead, an apparent suicide. The gun is in his right hand, yet the wound is on the left side of his head. A right-handed man does not shoot himself in such a manner.”  

I frowned. “But could he not have used his left hand?”  

“Possible, but unlikely. And then there is the matter of the papers on his desk. They were too neatly stacked, as though placed there deliberately. A man in the act of taking his own life does not pause to tidy his affairs so meticulously.”  

“Then you believe he was murdered?”  

“I am certain of it. The question is—by whom?”  

Holmes rose and began pacing the room, his long fingers steepled before him. “The widow is grief-stricken, but her distress seems genuine. The servants speak highly of their master, yet there is something amiss in the household. The butler, for instance—did you notice how his hands trembled when he spoke of his employer?”  

I had not, but I trusted Holmes’s powers of observation implicitly.  

“And then there is the matter of the missing ledger,” Holmes continued. “Mrs. Wainwright mentioned that her husband kept meticulous financial records, yet the most recent volume was not in its usual place.”  

“You think it was stolen?”  

“Or hidden. Either way, it is a thread we must pull.”  

The following morning, Holmes set out alone, instructing me to remain at Baker Street in case any new developments arose. It was not until late afternoon that he returned, his expression even graver than before.  

“Watson,” he said, sinking into his chair, “I have uncovered a web of deceit that stretches far beyond this single death. Mr. Wainwright was not merely a banker—he was a man who knew too much.”  

He proceeded to explain that Wainwright had discovered evidence of embezzlement within his firm, orchestrated by none other than his own partner, Mr. Edgar Holloway. The missing ledger contained the proof, and Holloway, fearing exposure, had arranged Wainwright’s murder to appear as suicide.  

“But how can we prove it?” I asked.  

Holmes’s lips curled into a thin smile. “By setting a trap. Holloway does not yet know that we suspect him. I have taken the liberty of sending him a message, purportedly from Wainwright himself, suggesting that a copy of the ledger exists.”  

That evening, as Holmes had predicted, Holloway arrived at the Wainwright residence under cover of darkness, intent on retrieving the incriminating document. He was met not by the silence of an empty house, but by the stern gaze of Sherlock Holmes and the waiting constables of Scotland Yard.  

As Holloway was led away in handcuffs, his face twisted with rage and fear, Holmes turned to me with a sigh. “Another case closed, Watson, yet the darkness remains. There will always be men like Holloway, willing to kill to protect their secrets.”  

I nodded, understanding now the weight that had settled upon my friend’s shoulders. For all his brilliance, Holmes was not a man who took pleasure in the capture of criminals. He saw too clearly the cost of their crimes—the lives shattered, the trust betrayed.  

As we walked back to Baker Street, the first light of dawn creeping over the rooftops of London, I knew that this case would linger in Holmes’s mind for some time. And though he would soon throw himself into another investigation, the shadow of this night’s work would not easily fade.  

For in the end, even the greatest detective could not escape the grim truth that evil, in all its forms, was never far from the streets he walked.

After silence, a gentle, continuous hissing sound becomes audible.
Instantly, Holmes strikes a match and furiously lashes the bell-rope with his cane, yelling at Watson.
Watson sees nothing but the glare and Holmes's horrified expression; he hears a low whistle.
A dreadful shriek of pain, fear, and anger erupts from Roylott's room, echoing through the night.
When silence returns, Holmes declares, "It means that it is all over."
He instructs Watson to bring his pistol as they enter Roylott's room.
Lighting the lamp, Holmes leads the way.
